DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN RESOURCES
§ 32.215 PURPOSE.
   It has been established by social and scientific evidence that the proper
and most efficient utilization of the resources, talents and abilities of those
persons employed by the city will result in the most efficient delivery of city
services to the residents and persons and firms which interact with the city;
thus, the purpose of this Department is to substantially contribute to the
efficient management of the city workforce and the delivery of city services by
the employees of the city.
(Prior Code, § 32.200) (Ord. 05-O-1841, passed 11-16-2005)
§ 32.216 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established an executive department of the city which shall
be known as the “Department of Human Resources”. The Department shall consist
of a Director and such other assistants, clerks and other employees as may be
necessary, all appointed by the Mayor with the advice and consent of the City
Council.
(Prior Code, § 32.201) (Ord. 05-O-1841, passed 11-16-2005)
§ 32.217 QUALIFICATIONS OF DIRECTOR.
   The Director shall possess the following qualifications for appointment to
the office:
   (A)   The appointee must have at least two years’ experience working in
human resources;
   (B)   Must possess strong customer service skills and team commitment;
   (C)   Excellent computer knowledge of Windows, MS Word, Excel and the like;
   (D)   Knowledge of HR policies and procedures;
   (E)   Excellent communications, interacting and writing skills; and
   (F)   Ability to handle multiple projects and deadlines on a regular basis.
(Prior Code, § 32.202) (Ord. 05-O-1841, passed 11-16-2005)
§ 32.218 SCOPE OF SUPERVISION.
   All non-appointed officers and employees of the city shall be under the
direct supervision and oversight of the Director and shall perform such duties
as may be required of them by the terms and conditions of their employment.
Heads of other executive departments shall not be under the direct supervision
of the Director of the Department of Human Resources.
(Prior Code, § 32.203) (Ord. 05-O-1841, passed 11-16-2005)
§ 32.219 RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Director of the Department of Human Resources shall be responsible for
the following aspects of the city workforce:
   (A)   Supports the day-to-day clerical requirements of Human Resources;
   (B)   Maintain complete and accurate filing system for all HR documents;
   (C)   Able to assist with recruiting functions, screening resumes;
   (D)   Providing administrative support working with employees to resolve
benefit issues;
   (E)   Assist with the revisions and communication of current and newly
developed policies and procedures;
   (F)   Assist with documentation process for accidents or incidents;
   (G)   Works with managers to improve corporate culture, motivation
strategies and encourages good will to all employees;
   (H)   Should work with administrative staff to ensure a productive work
environment;
   (I)   Handling all compensation and benefits distributed by the city;
   (J)   Conducting new hires orientation where required;
   (K)   Processing benefit claim information and following up on discrepancies
with third party providers;
   (L)   Verifying employee healthcare benefits eligibility;
   (M)   Inputting new employee data and updating current employees’ data
directly into software system; and
   (N)   Answering employee questions regarding benefits, eligibility and
explanation of benefits.
(Prior Code, § 32.204) (Ord. 05-O-1841, passed 11-16-2005)

ORDINANCE ENFORCEMENT DEPARTMENT
§ 32.245 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this subchapter is to establish a Code Violation Hearing
Court. This subchapter also makes provisions for the administrative composition
of this Court and establishes rules of procedure and other rules and
regulations in order to maintain a system to expedite the prosecution and
correction of code violations within the city.
(Prior Code, § 40.01) (Ord. 02-O-1737, passed 9-4-2002)
§ 32.246 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CODE. Any municipal ordinance, law, housing or building code or zoning code
that establishes construction, plumbing, heating, electrical, fire prevention,
sanitation or other health and safety standards that are applicable to
structures or property in the municipality.
   FAMILY UNIT. A room or group of rooms used or intended to be used as a
housekeeping unit of living sleeping, cooking and eating.
   HEARING OFFICER. An individual appointed by the Mayor of the city, whose
qualifications and duties are defined by state law and this chapter.
   INSPECTOR. Any employee of the city designated by the city to enforce codes
or similar laws, or his or her duly authorized representative.
   PROPERTY OWNER. One or more persons, a corporation, a partnership or any
other legal entity, jointly or severally in whom is vested all or part of the
legal title to the premises or all or part of the beneficial ownership and
right to present use and enjoyment of the premises, including a mortgage holder
in possession.
(Prior Code, § 40.02) (Ord. 02-O-1737, passed 9-4-2002)
§ 32.247 ADMINISTRATIVE COMPOSITION.
   The system of administrative adjudication of code violations shall provide
for a hearing system Code Compliance Administrator, Hearing Officer, Computer
Operator/System Coordinator and hearing room personnel with the power,
authority and limitations as are hereinafter set forth.
   (A)   The Code Compliance Administrator shall be empowered and is hereby
authorized and directed to:
      (1)   Operate and manage the system of administrative adjudication of
code violations;
      (2)   Adopt, distribute and process code violation notices and other
notices as may be required under this subchapter as may be reasonably required
to carry out the purposes of this subchapter;
      (3)   Collect money paid as fines or penalties and costs assessed after a
final determination of violations liability;
      (4)   Conduct hearings as a Hearing Officer; provided, he or she is
properly certified with the same power and authority as is hereinafter set
forth, during the absence of the appointed Hearing Officer;
      (5)   Certify copies of final determination(s) of Building Code violation
(s) liability and factual reports verifying that the final determination of
code violation liability was issued in accordance with this chapter;
      (6)   Promulgate rules and regulations reasonably required to operate and
maintain the administrative adjudication of code violation system hereby
created; and
      (7)   Collect unpaid fines and penalties by filing complaints in the
Circuit Court or selecting or appointing an individual or agency to act on
behalf of the city in filing complaints seeking judgments for unpaid fines or
penalties and pursuits of all post-judgment remedies available by current law.
   (B)   A Hearing Officer is a municipal employee or an officer or agent of a
municipality, other than a Director of Building and Housing or law enforcement
officer, whose duty it is to:
      (1)   Preside at an administrative hearing called to determine whether or
not a code violation exists;
      (2)   Hear testimony and accept evidence from the Code Inspector, the
building owner and all interested parties relevant to the existence of a code
violation;
      (3)   Preserve and authenticate the transcript and record of the hearing
and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing;
      (4)   Issue and sign a written finding, decision and order stating
whether a code violation exists;
      (5)   Issue subpoenas to secure the attendance of witnesses and
production of relevant papers or documentation;
      (6)   Assess fines, penalties and costs; and
      (7)   Make a final determination of code violation liability.
   (C)   The Computer Data Operator/System Coordinator is hereby authorized and
directed to operate and maintain the computer program(s) for the administrative
adjudication system hereby created, on a day-to-day basis, including, but not
limited to:
      (1)   Input of violation notice information;
      (2)   Hearing date(s) and notice dates;
      (3)   Fine and penalty assessments and payment(s);
      (4)   Issue payment receipts;
      (5)   Issue succeeding notices of hearing dates, final determination of
liability as directed by the hearing system Compliance Administrator in
accordance with the provisions hereinafter set forth; and
      (6)   Keep accurate records of appearances and non-appearances at
administrative hearings, pleas entered, fines and penalties assessed and paid.
   (D)   (1)   Hearing room personnel are hereby authorized and directed to:
         (a)   Maintain hearing room decorum;
         (b)   Have and execute authority as is granted to courtroom deputies
of the Circuit Court; and
         (c)   Perform such other duties or acts as may reasonably be required
and as directed by the Hearing Officer or hearing system Code Compliance
Administrator.
      (2)   The position is limited to off-duty, full-time, part-time or
auxiliary police officers.
   (E)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to appoint persons to hold the
positions above set forth. One person may hold and fulfill the requirements of
one or more of the above stated positions.
   (F)   The pay for each of the above stated positions shall be as recommended
by the Mayor, determined by the City Council and as contained in the annual
appropriation ordinance.
(Prior Code, § 40.03) (Ord. 02-O-1737, passed 9-4-2002)
§ 32.248 CODE HEARING PROCEDURES.
   (A)   Citation issuance. At the end of the time, the Code Inspector has
allowed for correction of any code violations previously cited and the property
re-inspected and it is determined by the Code Inspector or his or her
authorized representative that such violation has not been corrected, he or she
may issue a code violation citation. This citation will inform the owner of the
following:
      (1)   Name and address of the structure owner;
      (2)    Address of structure where the violation was observed;
      (3)   Type and nature of violation;
      (4)   Time and date violation was observed;
      (5)   Name of witnesses of the violation;
      (6)   Signature of Code Department representative; and
      (7)   Date, time and place of code violation hearing.
   (B)   One copy of the violation shall be retained by the Code Department for
its files, one copy given to the Code Compliance Administrator for processing
and one copy shall be served on the building owner at the time of issuance. If
the building owner is unavailable to receive a copy of the citation, it will be
served by first class mail. A summons from the Administrator stating the
citation number, date, time and place of the code violation hearing shall also
be served on the owner by the first class mail. If the building owner cannot be
ascertained or service on the owner cannot be made by nailing a copy of the
citation on the front door of the structure where the violation is found not
less than 20 days before the hearing is scheduled, service may also be made by
police in accordance with 65 ILCS 5/12-11, or in any manner provided by law.
   (C)   Hearing date. The hearing date shall not be less than 30 days nor more
than 40 days after the violation is reported by the Code Department.
   (D)   Subpoenas and defaults. At anytime prior to the hearing date, the
Hearing Officer assigned to hear the case may, at the request of the Director
of Building and Housing or the attorney for the city, or the owner or his or
her attorney, issue subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give testimony
at the hearing. If on the date set for the hearing the owner or his or her
attorney shall fail to appear, the Hearing Officer may find the owner in
default and shall proceed with the hearing and accept evidence relevant to the
existence of a code violation.
   (E)   Continuances and representation at Building Code hearing. 
      (1)   Continuances shall be granted at the discretion of the Hearing
Officer for good cause shown. This division (E) does not encourage continuances
in the interest of a speedy determination of the existence of the alleged
violation and the protection of the health, safety and welfare of the public.
Any continuance granted shall not be in excess of 28 days.
      (2)   The appearance of the representative of the Code Department is not
required unless there is a contest as to the existence of the alleged
violation. No employee of the Code Hearing Department may present a case for
the city. The case for the owner may be presented by the owner, or his or her
designated representative, who need not be an attorney. The case for the city
may be presented by any designated employee of the Code Department.
      (3)   The Code Hearing Administrator shall promulgate a form designated
“Appearance” to be executed by all participants in the hearing other than the
city and filed with the Hearing Officer.
   (F)   Hearing evidence.  
      (1)   At the hearing, the Hearing Officer shall preside and hear
testimony and accept any evidence relevant to the existence or non-existence of
a code violation, and steps taken or being taken to correct the violations. The
strict rules of evidence applicable to judicial proceedings shall not apply to
hearings authorized by this subchapter.
      (2)   The properly executed citation shall be prima facie evidence of the
existence of the alleged building violation and shall suffice for the entry of
a finding on behalf of the city by the Hearing Officer.
   (G)   Correction of violation before hearing. If the building owner corrects
the code violation and the Code Department re-inspects and approves the
corrections not less than seven days before the hearing date, the
representative may request that the Code Administrator cancel the hearing and
dismiss the citation.
(Prior Code, § 40.04) (Ord. 02-O-1737, passed 9-4-2002)
§ 32.249 DEFENSES TO CODE VIOLATIONS.
   It shall be a defense to a code violation under this chapter if the owner or
his or her representative proves to the satisfaction of the Hearing Officer
that:
   (A)   The Building Code violation alleged in the citation does not in fact
exist or at the time of the hearing the violation has been remedied or removed;
   (B)   The code violation has been caused by the current property occupants
and in spite of reasonable attempts by the owner to maintain the dwelling free
of such violations, the current occupants continue to cause the violations;
and/or
   (C)   An occupant or resident of the dwelling has refused entry to the owner
or his or her agent to all or part of the dwelling for the purpose of
correcting the code violation.
(Prior Code, § 40.05) (Ord. 02-O-1737, passed 9-4-2002)
§ 32.250 FINDINGS, DECISION AND ORDER.
   (A)   At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall make a
determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing as to
whether or not a building violation exists. The determination shall be in
writing and shall be designated as findings, decision and order, the decision
to be rendered within 30 days of the conclusion of the hearing. The findings,
decision and order shall include the Hearing Officer’s findings of fact, a
decision whether or not the violation alleged exists based on the finding of
fact, and an order, ordering the owner to correct the violation or dismissing
the case, in the event a violation is not proved. If a Building Code violation
is proved, the order may also impose sanctions, including, but not limited to,
fines that are provided in the maintenance code adopted by the city for the
violation(s) proved.
   (B)   A copy of the findings, decision and order shall be served on the
owner within five days after they are issued. Service shall be in the same
manner as the citation and summons are served pursuant to this subchapter.
   (C)   Payment of any fine, penalty or administrative costs imposed shall be
made to the city through the office of the City Clerk. When collected the
fines, penalties and administrative costs shall be paid into the General Fund
of the city.
   (D)   Payment of a fine does not relieve the owner of the obligation to
correct the violation, if not already accomplished.
(Prior Code, § 40.06) (Ord. 02-O-1737, passed 9-4-2002)
§ 32.251 EVICTION RIGHTS OF OCCUPANTS.
   No action of eviction, abatement of nuisance, forcible entry or detainer or
other similar proceeding shall be threatened or instituted against the occupant
of a dwelling solely because such occupant agrees to or does testify at a code
violation hearing on behalf of the city.
(Prior Code, § 40.07) (Ord. 02-O-1737, passed 9-4-2002)
§ 32.252 REVIEW UNDER ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW ACT.
   The findings, decision and order of the Hearing Officer shall be subject to
judicial review in the Circuit Court of the county pursuant to the provisions
of the Administrative Review Act, 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.
(Prior Code, § 40.08) (Ord. 02-O-1737, passed 9-4-2002)
§ 32.253 JUDGMENT ON FINDINGS, DECISION AND ORDER.
   (A)   Any fine, sanction or costs imposed or part of any fine, sanction or
costs imposed remaining unpaid after the exhaustion or failure to exhaust
judicial review procedures under the Administrative Review Act shall be a debt
due and owing to the city and as such may be collected in accordance with
applicable law.
   (B)   After expiration of the period within which judicial review may be
sought, the city may commence a proceeding by petition in the Circuit Court of
the county for the purpose of obtaining a judgment on the findings, decision
and order. The city may consolidate multiple findings, decisions and orders
against any owner in those proceedings. Upon commencement of the action, the
city shall file a certified copy of the findings, decision and order which
shall be accompanied by a certification that recites facts sufficient to show
that the findings, decision and order were issued in accordance with 65 ILCS 5/
11-31.1-1 et seq. and this chapter. Service of summons and a copy of the
petition so filed may be made by any method provided for by § 2-203 of the
state’s Code of Civil Procedure, 735 ILCS 5/2-203 or by certified mail, return
receipt requested; provided that, the total amount of the fines, or other
sanctions and costs imposed by the findings, decision and order does not exceed
$ 2,500. If the Court is satisfied that the findings, decision and order were
entered in accordance with 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq. and this chapter and
that the property owner had an opportunity to appear and for a hearing in
accordance with 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq. and for judicial review as provided
in 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq.
      (1)   The Court shall render judgment in favor of the city and against
the property owner for the amount indicated in the findings, decision and
order, plus costs. The judgment shall have the same force and effect and may be
enforced in the same manner as other judgments for the recovery of money; and
      (2)   The Court may also issue such other orders and injunctions as are
requested by the city to enforce the order of the Hearing Officer or correct a
Building Code violation.
(Prior Code, § 40.09) (Ord. 02-O-1737, passed 9-4-2002)
§ 32.254 SANCTIONS APPLICABLE TO OWNER AND PROPERTY.
   (A)   The order to correct a code violation and the sanctions imposed by the
city as a result of a finding of a code violation under this subchapter shall
attach to the property, as well as to the owner of the property, so that a
finding of code violation against one owner cannot be avoided by conveying or
transferring the property to another person. Any subsequent transferee or owner
of the property takes subject to the findings, decision and order of the
Hearing Officer.
   (B)   All decisions, orders and findings not complied with in terms of
correction of the violation cited or where a fine, penalty or cost is not paid
within 30 days of the entry of the decision shall be filed with the Recorder of
Deeds of the county as a lien in favor of the city.
(Prior Code, § 40.10) (Ord. 02-O-1737, passed 9-4-2002)
§ 32.255 FEDERAL GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS; MAINTENANCE OF PROPERTY.
   A person who contracts with the Federal Government or any agency thereof,
including, but not limited to, the Department of Housing and Urban Development,
to care for vacant residential real estate shall be responsible for maintaining
the property in accordance with the applicable provisions of the city’s code of
ordinances, including, but not limited to, ordinances dealing with health and
safety code violations.
(Prior Code, § 40.11) (Ord. 02-O-1737, passed 9-4-2002)
§ 32.999 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.99 of this code of ordinances.
   (B)   Any person, firm or corporation that does not obey the Director of
Building and Housing as he or she performs his or her duties and exercise his
or her power as stated in §§
32.030 through
32.039 of this chapter, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than $25, nor
more than $100, for each offense. A separate offense is deemed committed each
day on which any work in violation of such order is done.
   (C)   Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of §
32.090 of this chapter, upon conviction, be fined not less than $5, nor more
than $50, for each offense. A separate offense is deemed committed each day on
which any work in violation of such order is done.
   (D)   (1)   Any person violating any of the provisions of §§
32.140 through
32.142 of this chapter shall be subject to a fine not exceeding $750 for each
offense with each and every day that a violation of §§
32.140 through
32.142 of this chapter has been allowed to remain in effect being deemed a
separate and distinct offense. In addition, the appropriate authorities of the
city may take such other actions they deem proper to enforce the terms and
conditions of §§
32.140 through
32.142 of this chapter, including without limitation, an action in the Circuit
Court of the county.
      (2)   Any person violating the terms of §§
32.140 through
32.142 of this chapter shall be subject, in addition to the foregoing
penalties, to the payment of court costs and reasonable attorney fees to the
city.
(Prior Code, § 32.999)
   (E)   (1)   The fines and penalties which shall be imposed for the violation
of §§
32.245 through
32.255 of this chapter shall be not less than $100, nor more than $500, for
each offense and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day
during which a violation occurs or continues.
      (2)   A person who intentionally violates §
32.255 of this chapter shall be guilty of a business offense and shall be fined
not less than $100, nor more than $500.
      (3)   The Hearing Officer shall have authority to impose an
administrative cost against the property owner in the decision based upon the
administrative costs of prosecuting the matter, the expense to be not less than
$25, nor more than $200.
      (4)   In addition to the penalty provided for in this division (E), the
city may file suit in the appropriate court seeking demolition, repair, board-
up, enclosure or such other relief as might be provided for by the laws,
statutes and rules and regulations of the state.
(Prior Code, § 40.99)
(Ord. 69-O-697, passed - -1968; Ord. 02-O-1737, passed 9-4-2002; Ord. 08-O-
1921, passed 4-16-2008; Ord. 09-O-1950, passed 6-3-2009)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 33.01 CREATION OF DEPARTMENT; ORGANIZATION.
   There is created a Police Department of the city which shall consist of the
following permanent positions:
   (A)   One Chief of Police;
   (B)   One Deputy Chief of Police;
   (C)   One Police Commander;
   (D)   One lieutenant;
   (E)   Four sergeants;
   (F)   Twenty-two patrol officers.
(Prior Code, § 33.01) (Ord. 71-O-764, passed - -1971; Ord. 72-O-796, passed - -
1972; Ord. 03-O-1749, passed 1-2-2003; Ord. 22-O-2329, passed 5-4-2022)
§ 33.02 RANK OF OFFICERS.
   The Chief of Police shall be the head of the Department and have supervision
over all officers and members thereof. Following him or her in rank shall be
the Deputy Chiefs, the Police Commander, the lieutenants, the sergeants and
patrol officers in order of seniority in each group.
(Prior Code, § 33.02) (Ord. 71-O-764, passed - -1971; Ord. 03-O-1750, passed 1-
2-2003; Ord. 22-O-2329, passed 5-4-2022)
§ 33.03 CHIEF OF POLICE; DUTIES.
   (A)   The Chief of Police shall keep such records and make such reports
concerning the activities of his or her Police Department as may be required by
statute or by the Mayor.
   (B)   The Chief shall be responsible for the performance by the Police
Department of its functions, and all persons who are members of the Police
Department shall serve subject to the orders of the Chief.
   (C)   The Chief of Police is exempt from the age of retirement for police
officers set forth in 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-17.
(Prior Code, § 33.04) (Ord. 71-O-764, passed - -1971; Ord. 23-O-2364, passed 6-
21-2023)
§ 33.04 ASSISTANT CHIEF OF POLICE.
   There is created the position of Assistant Chief of Police. One or more
Assistant Chiefs of Police may be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and
consent of the City Council. Anyone appointed to the position of Assistant
Chief of Police shall work with and assist the Chief of Police in his or her
duties and shall serve in such capacities as directed by the Chief. While
appointed Assistant Chief of Police, a person shall maintain his or her rank or
position, and pay, attained under the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners.
(Prior Code, § 33.05) (Ord. 73-O-835, passed - -1973)
§ 33.05 DEPARTMENTAL DUTIES.
   It shall be the duty of the members of the Police Department to see to the
enforcement of the ordinances of the city and all statutes applicable therein;
and to preserve order and prevent infractions of the law and arrest violators
thereof.
(Prior Code, § 33.06) (Ord. 71-O-764, passed - -1971)
§ 33.06 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Chief of the Police Department may make or prescribe such rules and
regulations as he or she shall deem advisable; such rules, when approved by the
City Council, shall be binding on such members. Such rules and regulations may
cover, besides the conduct of the members, uniforms and equipment to be worn or
carried, hours of service, vacations and all other similar matters necessary or
desirable for the better efficiency of the Police Department.
(Prior Code, § 33.07) (Ord. 71-O-764, passed - -1971)
§ 33.07 RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT.
   (A)   Sworn personnel of the Police Department of the city, whose original
or promotional appointments are subject to the authority of the Board of Police
and Fire Commissioners are required to be residents of the city.
   (B)   New personnel shall be allowed a period of one year following their
appointment to the Police Department to establish their residence in fact
within the geographical confines of the city.
(Prior Code, § 33.08) (Ord. 71-O-764, passed - -1971; Ord. 74-O-862, passed - -
1974)
§ 33.08 DEPUTY CHIEFS OF POLICE.
   (A)   There are hereby created two positions of Deputy Chief of Police.
   (B)   The Deputy Chiefs of Police shall be chosen by the Police Chief. The
positions shall be non-Board of Fire and Police Commissioners tested/appointed
ranks. Appointment to this position may be made from time to time. While
appointed, a Deputy Chief shall be on leave from his or her Board of Fire and
Police Commissioners rank.
   (C)   A Deputy Chief of Police shall be a sworn police officer and shall
have all powers and authority as specified by the Police Chief and shall serve
in such capacity as directed by the Police Chief. A Deputy Chief may be removed
by the Police Chief without cause at which time he or she shall return to his
or her Board of Fire and Police Commissioners rank.
(Prior Code, § 33.09) (Ord. 03-O-1748, passed 1-2-2003)
§ 33.08.01 POLICE COMMANDER.
   (A)   There is hereby created one position of Police Commander.
   (B)   The Police Commander shall be chosen by the Mayor. The position shall
be a non-Board of Fire and Police Commissioners tested/appointed rank. While
appointed, a Police Commander shall be on leave from his or her Board of Fire
and Police Commissioners rank.
   (C)   A Police Commander shall be a sworn police officer and shall have all
powers and authority as specified by the Mayor and the Police Chief and shall
serve in such capacity as directed by the Mayor and the Police Chief. A Police
Commander may be removed by the Mayor without cause, at which time he or she
shall return to his or her Board of Fire and Police Commissioners rank.
(Ord. 22-O-2329, passed 5-4-2022)
§ 33.09 CONDUCT OF MEMBERS.
   It shall be the duty of every member of the Police Department to conduct
himself or herself, in a proper and law-abiding manner, at all times, and to
avoid the use of unnecessary force. Each member of the Department shall obey
the orders and directions of his or her superior.
(Prior Code, § 33.10) (Ord. 71-O-764, passed - -1971)
§ 33.10 CAUSE FOR DISMISSAL.
   The failure of such personnel of the city to comply with such residency
requirement as set forth in this chapter shall be cause for dismissal of such
personnel from the Police Department.
(Prior Code, § 33.11) (Ord. 74-O-862, passed - -1974)
§ 33.11 SERVING PROCESS.
   No member of the Police Department, except the Chief of Police, shall serve
any process, except on command of the Chief.
(Prior Code, § 33.12) (Ord. 71-O-764, passed - -1971)
§ 33.12 FEES.
   (A)   Witness fees.
      (1)   Every member of the Police Department shall appear as a witness
whenever this is necessary in a prosecution for a violation of an ordinance or
of any state or federal law.
      (2)   No such member shall retain any witness fee for service as witness
in any action or suit to which the city is a party; any fees paid for such
services shall be turned over to the Chief of Police, who shall deposit the
same with the City Treasurer.
   (B)   Criminal history record. Upon payment of a $25 fee, completion of
application and a state drivers’ license or state identification card, the
city’s Police Department shall issue a criminal history record to the
requesting person.
   (C)   Expunging or sealing criminal record. Upon payment of a $60 fee,
completion of application and presentation of a signed and dated court order,
criminal history information from the State Police Department and a state
drivers’ license or state identification card, the city’s Police Department
shall expunge and/or seal the criminal record of the requesting person.
(Prior Code, § 33.13) (Ord. 71-O-764, passed - -1971; Ord. 09-O-1945, passed 5-
6-2009; Ord. 09-O-1946, passed 5-6-2009)
§ 33.13 CUSTODY OF STOLEN PROPERTY.
   The Chief of Police shall have the custody of all lost, abandoned or stolen
property recovered in the city.
(Prior Code, § 33.14) (Ord. 71-O-764, passed - -1971)
§ 33.14 REWARDS.
   The Chief of Police, for meritorious service rendered by any member of the
Police Force in the due discharge of his or her duty, may permit such member to
retain for his or her benefit, so far as he or she may be permitted by law, any
reward or present tendered him or her therefor, and it shall be cause of
removal for any member of the force to receive any such reward or present
without notice thereof to the Chief and without his or her permission.
(Prior Code, § 33.15) (Ord. 71-O-764, passed - -1971)
§ 33.15 POLICE COMMUNITY RELATIONS OFFICER.
   (A)   There is created the office of Police Community Relations Officer. The
Officer shall be appointed by the Mayor. The compensation of the Officer shall
be as determined from time to time by appropriation by the City Council.
   (B)   The Officer shall have the qualifications for a municipal officer
provided by the laws of the state and shall have a rapport with and working
knowledge of the Police Department of the city and the community of the city.
   (C)   The Officer shall promote good relations between the Police Department
and the community and shall work in close cooperation with the Chief of Police
and the Mayor in promoting this goal.
(Prior Code, § 33.16) (Ord. 73-O-825, passed - -1973)
§ 33.16 RECORDS AND INFORMATION OFFICER.
   (A)   There is created the position of Records and Information Officer.
   (B)   The Officer shall meet the requirements of an officer as established
by the law of the state.
   (C)   The Officer shall be appointed by the City Manager.
   (D)   The Officer shall manage and control the records of the Police
Department and shall operate under the direction of the Chief of Police.
(Prior Code, § 33.17) (Ord. 74-O-853, passed - -1974)
§ 33.17 POLICE DEPARTMENT CHAPLAIN.
   (A)   There is created and established the honorary position of Chaplain of
the Police Department of the city.
   (B)   The position shall be an honorary position only, qualifying neither as
an office, nor as a position of employment in the city.
   (C)   The position shall be filled by appointment by the Mayor of the city
annually, at the commencement of the fiscal year or as soon as practicable
thereafter.
   (D)   Appointments to the position created in this chapter shall be limited
to persons duly ordained as religious of a generally recognized religious sect.
   (E)   This section is not deemed to constitute an endorsement or
establishment by the city of any religious belief, persuasion or sect.
(Prior Code, § 33.18)
§ 33.18 SPECIAL POLICE.
   Any person of good character having duties which require it may be appointed
a special police officer by the Mayor; provided that, except upon authorization
by the City Council, no such special police officer shall be entitled to any
compensation from the city, nor shall such special police officer be considered
an employee of the city by reason of such appointment. Special police officer
shall obey all rules of the Police Department applicable to them, and may be
deprived of their appointment by the Chief of Police at any time.
(Prior Code, § 33.19) (Ord. 71-O-764, passed - -1971)
§ 33.19 PART-TIME POLICE OFFICERS.
   (A)   Part-time police officers shall be appointed by the Mayor with the
advice and consent of the City Council in such numbers as the Mayor and City
Council may from time to time determine to be necessary.
   (B)   Part-time police officers shall serve when called upon by the Mayor or
Chief of Police under the supervision of the regular Police Department. They
shall be conservators of the peace with the power to make arrests as provided
by statute.
   (C)   All applicants for the position of part-time police officer must be
certified State Police officers, comply with all state laws requiring
certification standards and meet the following hiring standards of the city:
      (1)   Must be at least 21 years old;
      (2)   Must be a high school graduate or equivalent;
      (3)   Must possess a valid Illinois driver’s license and have a good
driving record;
      (4)   Must be in good physical condition and pass any physical
examination and drug test required by the city;
      (5)   Must successfully complete all training required by statute,
ordinance or departmental regulation;
      (6)   Must submit to an oral interview with the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners;
      (7)   Must be of good character without a conviction for a felony or
crime involving moral turpitude and pass a thorough background examination;
      (8)   Must pass any written, polygraph and/or psychological tests
required by the city;
      (9)   Must have fingerprints submitted to the state and FBI for purposes
of checking criminal history;
         (10)   Part-time officers shall be compensated at a rate set from time
to time by the Mayor and City Council. These officers shall be compensated only
for actual hours worked;
         (11)   Part-time officers shall report to the full-time officer in
charge of the shift when they begin and end their tour of duty;
         (12)   Any part-time police officer who is terminated or leaves the
position within two years of appointment shall reimburse the city for all
training costs and expenses incurred by the city during said time. If any funds
are due the officer, they may be used by the city to pay a portion or all of
the training costs and expenses;
         (13)   A part-time police officer has no vested interest in the
position. Said officers acquire no rights and benefits not conferred by
statute. A city may discipline or discharge a part-time officer at any time. A
part-time officer shall be a member of the regular police department except for
pension purposes. They shall not be assigned to supervise or direct full-time
police officers and they shall not be used as permanent replacements for
permanent full-time police officers; and
         (14)   Part-time police officers shall work no more than 30 hours per
week or as may be regulated by statute.
(Prior Code, § 33.20) (Ord. 06-O-1851, passed 4-5-2006)
§ 33.20 HIRING OF LATERAL TRANSFER POLICE PATROL OFFICERS.
   (A)   That the Markham Board of Fire and Police Commissioners is hereby
authorized to hire police patrol officers for employment with the City of
Markham Police Department who have not been originally selected by the Board of
Fire and Police Commissioners, provided such officers have been employed,
whether currently or in the past, for at least two years as a full time sworn
law enforcement officer in any state, county, university or municipal law
enforcement agency (part-time certification as a law enforcement officer does
not meet this requirement); are in good standing with the agency in which they
currently serve or previously served; have successfully completed the Illinois
Basic Law Enforcement Academy and possess certification from the Illinois Law
Enforcement Standards and Training Board or are qualified to take the Illinois
Law Enforcement Standards and Training Board examination (part-time
certification as a law enforcement officer does not meet this requirement); are
United States citizens; are at least 21 years old at the time of application;
have a high school diploma or equivalent thereof; have a valid driver's
license; have no felony convictions and have good moral character as described
in 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-6; have not had any administrative charges filed by any
employer nor any charges of violence filed by any civilians in criminal or
civil courts or administratively; and have not had any disciplinary cases or
complaints filed by any employer.
   (B)   Applicants must agree to comply with all requirements, procedures,
qualifications and standards of the position of police patrol officer set forth
in the Board of Fire and Police Commission Rules and Regulations and have the
ability to pass all examination and training requirements, including but not
limited to, background investigation, psychological examination, medical
examination, drug screening and oral interview.
   (C)   Applicants shall furnish upon request a copy of the following, to the
extent applicable: a resume; professional licenses; training certificates;
documents confirming work experience; birth certificate; high school diploma or
GED certificate; transcripts of higher learning; and naval or military service
board and discharge papers (DD-214/Copy 40).
   (D)   The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners is hereby directed to
certify all applicants who satisfy all requirements set forth in this section
and Board of Fire and Police Commission Rules and Regulations to the Chief of
the City of Markham Police Department as being eligible for appointment as
full-time police patrol officers.
   (E)   Applicants are allowed to bring with them no more than four years of
police service from their prior employer for pension purposes. Applicants will
be on probation for one year from the date of hire. Applicants must
successfully complete their probationary period.
   (F)   Questions regarding participation in the City of Markham Police
Department Pension Fund shall be directed to and answered by that fund.
   (G)   Any lateral transfer of any police patrol officer hired after May 1,
2020 and the effective date of this Ord. 22-O-2325 shall be entitled to the
same rights and benefits of current full-time non-lateral police patrol
officers as set forth under Illinois law, this code, and Markham Board of Fire
and Police Commission Rules and Regulations.
(Ord. 21-O-2295, passed 3-17-2021; Ord. 21-O-2305, passed 7-21-2021; Ord. 22-O-
2325, passed 2-16-2022)
OTHER DIVISIONS OF DEPARTMENT
§ 33.30 JUVENILE DIVISION.
   (A)   There is created a division of the Police Department to be known as
the “Juvenile Division”, which shall be composed of such officers and employees
as the City Council may provide for from time to time.
   (B)   The Chief of Police shall assign to such Juvenile Division such
members of the Department as are considered qualified by experience and
training to properly perform the functions of the office.
   (C)   The members of the Division shall be under the general supervision and
direction of the Chief and be subject to the same rules and regulations as
other members of the Department.
(Prior Code, § 33.30) (Ord. 71-O-764, passed - -1971)
§ 33.31 OTHER DIVISIONS.
   The Chief of Police may establish a Plainclothes Division or other special
division within the Police Department, assigning such police officers to such
Division and designating such duties therefor as may be deemed necessary.
(Prior Code, § 33.31) (Ord. 71-O-764, passed - -1971)
POLICE DEPARTMENT EXAMINATIONS
§ 33.45 DEFINITION.
   ELECTOR shall have the same meaning as set forth in the Illinois Municipal
Code.
(Prior Code, § 33.40) (Ord. 76-O-908, passed - -1976; Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-
4-1987)
§ 33.46 RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT FOR EXAMINATION.
   No person shall be eligible to take part in any competitive examination or
portion thereof conducted by or pursuant to the authority of the Board of Fire
and Police Commissioners of the city, for the purpose of establishing a list of
eligibles for appointment to positions on the Police Department of the city,
unless such person is an elector of the city, and shall have been an actual
resident of the city for a period of not less than 180 days prior to the date
of the commencement of such examination.
(Prior Code, § 33.41) (Ord. 76-O-908, passed - -1976; Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-
4-1987)
§ 33.47 ADMITTANCE TO EXAMINATIONS.
   No person shall be admitted to or be allowed to participate as an examinee
in any competitive examination, or any portion thereof, conducted by or under
the authority of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners of the city, for
the purpose of establishing a list of eligibles for appointment to positions in
the Police Department, unless such person is an elector of the city and shall
have been an actual resident of the city for a period of not less than 180 days
prior to the date of the commencement of such examination.
(Prior Code, § 33.42) (Ord. 76-O-908, passed - -1976; Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-
4-1987)
§ 33.48 PROOF OF ELECTOR STATUS.
   No person shall be admitted to nor allowed to participate as an examinee in
any competitive examination, or any portion thereof, conducted by or under the
authority of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners of the city, for the
purpose of establishing a list of eligibles for appointment to positions on the
Police Department, unless such person shall have first submitted to the Board
of Fire and Police Commissioners satisfactory proof of his or her status as an
elector of the city, and proof of actual residence within the city as required
in this subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 33.43) (Ord. 76-O-908, passed - -1976; Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-
4-1987)
§ 33.49 ESTABLISHMENT OF PROOF.
   Proof of elector status and residence may be established by reference to
records of public or private persons, firms, corporations, organizations and
political subdivisions of the state, which records contain material competent
to establish the status of a person as an elector of the city. Proof of such
status may also be established by affidavit of not less than two persons who
themselves are duly qualified electors of the city, and who shall have been
residents of the city for a period sufficient to prima facie establish such
person’s ability to affirm the contents of such affidavit.
(Prior Code, § 33.44) (Ord. 76-O-908, passed - -1976; Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-
4-1987)
POLICE PENSION FUND
§ 33.60 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
   There shall be a Police Pension Fund established for the city as provided by
law.
(Prior Code, § 33.55)
§ 33.61 BOARD OF TRUSTEES ESTABLISHED.
   There is established a Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund, which
shall be known as the “Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund” of the
city. The Pension Board shall consist of five members who are residents of the
city, two appointed by the Mayor and two elected by the members of the Police
Department, and one elected by the beneficiaries of the Pension Fund. The
elections shall be held on the third Monday in April and the term of each
member shall be two years. The Pension Board shall hold at least quarterly
meetings as provided by law, on the second Tuesday of July, October, January
and April of each year, and shall hold such additional meetings as may be
called by the President of the Pension Board.
(Prior Code, § 33.56)
§ 33.62 ORGANIZATION, DUTIES AND AUTHORITY.
   The Police Pension Board shall, on the second Tuesday of July of each year,
select its president and its secretary from its membership, each of whom shall
act for the period of one year or until such time as their successors are
elected and qualified. The Pension Board shall have such additional officers
and such duties and authority as provided by law.
(Prior Code, § 33.57)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 34.01 DEFINITION.
   ELECTOR shall have the same meaning as set forth in the Illinois Municipal
Code.
(Prior Code, § 34.01) (Ord. 76-O-908, passed - -1976; Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-
4-1987)
§ 34.02 PERMANENT DEPARTMENT CREATED.
   (A)   In addition to the Volunteer Fire Department, there is created a Fire
Department of the city which shall consist of the following permanent
positions:
      (1)   One Fire Chief;
      (2)   Deputy Chiefs;
      (3)   Lieutenants;
      (4)   Engineers; and
      (5)   Firefighters.
   (B)   The number of each rank between firefighters and Deputy Chief will be
as determined by the corporate authorities.
(Prior Code, § 34.02) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987; Ord. 96-O-1573, passed
3- -1995)
§ 34.03 APPOINTMENTS.
   (A)   All appointments to or promotions within the Fire Department shall be
made by the Fire and Police Commissioners as provided by law; except that, the
Fire Chief and the Deputy Chiefs shall not be appointed by the Board of Fire
and Police Commissioners. The Mayor shall appoint and discharge the Fire Chief
and the Deputy Chiefs.
   (B)   (1)   The city’s Board of Fire and Police Commissioners is hereby
authorized to hire firefighters for duty with the city’s Fire Department who
have not been originally selected by the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners; provided, such proposed employee has been employed as a
firefighter with another Illinois fire department; that the proposed applicant
has taken and successfully passed all preliminary testing for their initial
appointment as firefighter and he or she is certified by the state as a
firefighter; that there are no pending administrative charges against the
applicant by their current employer, nor have they been charged with acts of
violence by civilians in either the civil courts or administratively; further
that, the applicant has not had disciplinary problems with the city.
      (2)   The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners is hereby directed to
certify all such proposed employees to the Chief of the city’s Fire Department
as being eligible for appointment as firefighters.
      (3)   Such firefighters are allowed to bring with them their seniority
rank for pension purposes from their prior employer; the applicant will be on
probation for one year and not achieving the pay scale for his or her seniority
level until he or she has successfully completed the probationary period.
      (4)   The applicant must undergo the standard physical evaluation and
testing, be tested for drug use and the applicant must execute a statement
agreeing to stay with the city’s Fire Department for a period of at least one
year and that, should he or she depart prior to the expiration of such one-year
period, then the applicant shall reimburse the city for the cost of such
initial testing as he or she has undergone.
      (5)   Any questions regarding participation in the city’s Fire Department
Pension Fund shall be resolved by that Fund.
(Prior Code, § 34.03) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987; Ord. 08-O-1923, passed
5-21-2008)
§ 34.04 CHAIN OF COMMAND.
   The Fire Chief shall be the head of the Fire Department and have supervision
over all officers and members thereof. Following him or her in the chain of
command shall be the Deputy Chiefs, the lieutenants, the engineers and the
firefighters in order of seniority in each group.
(Prior Code, § 34.04) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987; Ord. 96-O-1573, passed
3- -1995)
§ 34.05 FIRE CHIEF; DUTIES.
   (A)   The Fire Chief shall be responsible for the performance and operation
of the full-time and volunteer firefighters.
   (B)   All persons who are members or employees of the full-time and
volunteer Fire Department shall serve subject to the order of the Fire Chief.
(Prior Code, § 34.05) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987)
§ 34.06 DEPUTY FIRE CHIEF; DUTIES.
   (A)   The organizational structure of the city’s Fire Department should be
revised to eliminate the position of captain and to create an administrative,
non-bargaining unit, position to be known as the Deputy Chief of the City Fire
Department.
   (B)   The duties and job description of the position of Deputy Chief of the
Fire Department shall be as promulgated from time to time by the Chief
Administrative officer of the city’s Fire Department in consultation with the
Mayor.
   (C)   The salary and benefits appertaining to the position of the Deputy
Chief of the Fire Department shall be as designated by an appropriate ordinance
passed by the City Council and approved by the Mayor, according to law.
(Prior Code, § 34.06) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987; Ord. 96-O-1573, passed
3- -1995)
§ 34.07 DEPARTMENTAL DUTIES.
   Members of the Fire Department shall perform all the duties delegated to
them by state law, and the code and all applicable ordinances, rules and
procedures of the city. Firefighters shall acquire the knowledge of operation
of all apparatus, tools and equipment in use in the Department, and maintain
such apparatus, tools and equipment in a clean condition and in readiness for
operation at all times. Firefighters shall observe and study the principles of
modern firefighting, fire prevention, rescue work, resuscitation, first aid,
ventilation and salvage operations. Members shall constantly promote their
physical and mental welfare. It shall be the duty of all members thereof to
extinguish accidental or destructive fires and to prevent the occurrence or
spread of such fires. It shall be the duty of all members thereof to provide
rescue emergency medical services and to promote fire prevention within the
community.
(Prior Code, § 34.07) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987)
§ 34.08 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (A)   The Fire Chief may make or prescribe such rules and regulations as he
or she shall deem advisable. Such rules and regulations, when approved by the
City Council, shall be binding on the members of the Department.
   (B)   The rules attached to Ord. 88-O-1313 as “Exhibit A” are adopted as the
rules for the Fire Department and are made a part hereof by reference as if set
out in full herein.
(Prior Code, § 34.08) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987; Ord. 88-O-1313, passed
5-18-1988)
§ 34.09 RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT.
   Sworn personnel of the Fire Department whose original or promotional
appointments are subject to the Board of Fire and Police are required to be
residents of the city. New personnel shall have resided in the city at least
six months prior to examination. Failure to remain a city resident shall be the
basis for dismissal of sworn personnel.
(Prior Code, § 34.09) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987)
§ 34.10 FEES AND CHARGES.
   (A)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      ALARM SYSTEM. Any automatic, manual or electronic system which generates
a telephonic or electronic call to the Fire Department for the dispatch of
equipment and personnel to a particular location.
      FALSE ALARM. The giving of an automatic telephone or electronic signal to
the Fire Department that services are needed at a particular location together
with a response by the Fire Department involving the dispatch of fire equipment
and personnel where there was no fire or life threatening situation.
      INSPECTION AND TESTING FOR MISCELLANEOUS ITEMS. Inspection and testing of
premises and/or equipment by the Fire Department based on a request by the
owner or lessee of the premises or equipment.
      INSPECTION FOR PAST DUE VIOLATIONS. Those inspections called for in order
to determine compliance with the Fire Prevention Code where a citation has
previously been issued for a violation of that code.
      OPENING INSPECTION. That inspection called for based upon an application
for the issuance of a business license by the city.
   (B)   Assessment of fees. The person, firm or corporation against whom the
fee is to be assessed shall be notified, in writing, within 30 days of the date
of rendering of the service in question of the amount of fees due and a demand
for payment within 30 days. This notification shall be mailed to the owner or
lessee at the address to which the Fire Department equipment and personnel
responded.
   (C)   Delinquent fees. All fees assessed shall become delinquent in the
event the fee is not paid within 30 days of the date of mailing of the
notification to the address as indicated above. Fees not paid within 30 days of
notification will be assessed a penalty of 50% as so much additional charge for
non-payment.
   (D)   Collection of delinquent fees. The city is hereby authorized to take
whatever action necessary to collect delinquent fees and penalties including,
but not limited to, reference to a collection agency or the institution of
legal action. The owner and/or lessee of the premises in question shall be
liable, as an additional charge, for such reasonable attorneys fees and cost of
collection as the court may assess.
   (E)   Fees and charges. There shall be charged to all persons, firms,
corporations or such other entities as shall request and received services from
the Fire Department of the city a fee for such services as set forth below:
Service Provided Fee

§ 34.26 [RESERVED.]
§ 34.27 MITIGATION RATES FOR EMERGENCY AND NON-EMERGENCY SERVICES.
   (A)   The city shall initiate mitigation rates for the delivery of emergency
and non-emergency services by the fire department for personnel, supplies and
equipment to the scene of emergency and non-emergency incidents as listed in
“Exhibit A”. The mitigation rates shall be based on actual costs of the
services and that which is usual, customary and reasonable (UCR) as shown in
“Exhibit A”, which may include any services, personnel, supplies and equipment
and with baselines established by addendum to the ordinance codified herein.
   (B)   A claim shall be filed to the responsible party through their
insurance carrier. In some circumstances, the responsible party will be billed
directly.
   (C)   The City Council may make rules or regulations and from time to time
may amend, revoke or add rules and regulations, not consistent with this
section, as it may deem necessary or expedient in respect to billing for these
mitigation rated or the collection thereof.
(Ord. 14-O-2088, passed 3-5-2014; Ord. 22-O-2341, passed 10-19-2022)
FIRE PENSION FUND
§ 34.40 FUND ESTABLISHED.
   There shall be a fire pension fund established for the city as provided by
law.
(Prior Code, § 34.55) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987)
§ 34.41 BOARD OF TRUSTEES ESTABLISHED.
   There is established a Board of Trustees of the Firefighters Pension Fund
which shall be known as the Board of Trustees of the Fire Pension Fund of the
city. The Board of Trustees shall consist of the City Treasurer, City Clerk,
Fire Chief, Mayor, three active firefighters and one retired firefighter.
(Prior Code, § 34.56) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987)
§ 34.42 ORGANIZATION; DUTIES AND AUTHORITY.
   (A)   The members chosen from the active and retired firefighters shall be
elected by ballot at elections to be held on the third Monday in April of the
applicable years under the Australian ballot system, at such place or places,
in the municipality, and under such regulations as shall be prescribed by the
Pension Board.
   (B)   No person shall cast more than one vote for each candidate from whom
he or she is eligible to vote. In the elections for Board members to be chosen
from the active firefighters, all active firefighters and no others may vote.
In the elections for Board members to be chosen from retired firefighters, the
retired firefighters and no others may vote.
   (C)   Each member of the Board so elected shall hold office for a term of
three years and until his or her successor has been duly elected and qualified.
   (D)   The Board shall canvass the ballots and declare which persons have
been elected and for what term or terms respectively. In the case of a tie vote
between two more candidates, the Board shall determine by lot which candidate
or candidates have been elected and for what term or terms respectively. In the
event of the failure, resignation or inability to act of any Board member, a
successor shall be elected for the unexpired term at a special election called
by the Board and conducted in the same manner as a regular election.
   (E)   The Board shall elect annually from its members a President and
Secretary.
   (F)   Board members shall not receive or have any right to receive any
salary from a pension fund for services performed as Board members.
(Prior Code, § 34.57) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987)
FIRE DEPARTMENT EXAMINATIONS
§ 34.55 DEFINITION.
   ELECTOR shall have the same meaning as set forth in the Illinois Municipal
Code.
(Prior Code, § 34.65) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987)
§ 34.56 RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT FOR EXAMINATION.
   No person shall be eligible to take part in any competitive examination or
portion thereof conducted by or pursuant to the authority of the Board of Fire
and Police Commissioners of the city, for the purpose of establishing a list of
eligibles for appointment to positions on the Fire Department of the city,
unless such person is an elector of the city, and shall have been an actual
resident of the city for a period of not less than 180 days prior to the date
of the commencement of such examination.
(Prior Code, § 34.66) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987)
§ 34.57 ADMITTANCE TO EXAMINATIONS.
   No person shall be admitted to or be allowed to participate as an examinee
in any competitive examination, or any portion thereof, conducted by or under
the authority of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners of the city, for
the purpose of establishing a list of eligibles for appointment to positions in
the Fire Department, unless such person is an elector of the city and shall
have been an actual resident of the city for a period of not less than 180 days
prior to the date of the commencement of such examination.
(Prior Code, § 34.67) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987)
§ 34.58 PROOF OF ELECTOR STATUS.
   No person shall be admitted to nor allowed to participate as an examinee in
any competitive examination, or any portion thereof, conducted by or under the
authority of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners of the city, for the
purpose of establishing a list of eligibles for appointment to positions on the
Fire Department, unless such person shall have first submitted to the Board of
Fire and Police Commissioners satisfactory proof of his status as an elector of
the city, and proof of actual residence within the city as required in this
subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 34.68) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987)
§ 34.59 ESTABLISHMENT OF PROOF.
   Proof of elector status and residence may be established by reference to
records of public or private persons, firms, corporations, organizations and
political subdivisions of the state, which records contain material competent
to establish the status of a person as an elector of the city. Proof of such
status may also be established by affidavit of not less than two persons who
themselves are duly qualified electors of the city, and who shall have been
residents of the city for a period sufficient to prima facie establish such
person’s ability to affirm the contents of such affidavit.
(Prior Code, § 34.69) (Ord. 87-O-1261, passed 2-4-1987)
FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES
§ 34.70 TAX IMPOSED.
   Any corporation, company or association not incorporated under the laws of
the state which is engaged in the city in effecting fire insurance shall pay
the City Treasurer, for the maintenance, use and benefit of the Fire Department
of the city, a sum of money equal in amount to 2% per year of the gross
receipts received as premiums upon fire insurance policies by any and all
agents of the corporation, company or association, during the year ending on
July 1 in each year, for any insurance effected, or agreed to be effected on
property located in the city, by or with such corporation, company or
association during such year.
(Ord. 24-O-2394, passed 9-4-2024)
§ 34.71 REPORT BY AGENT TO BE MADE TO CITY CLERK.
   (A)   Every person acting in the city as agent, for or on behalf of any such
fire insurance corporation, company or association, shall, on or before July 15
of each year, render the City Clerk a full, true and just account verified by
his or her oath, of all premiums upon fire insurance policies which, during the
year ending the July 1 preceding such report, shall have been received by him
or her, or by some other person for him or her, in his or her behalf of any
such corporation, company or association on property located in the city.
   (B)   Such agent shall also at the time of rendering the report, pay to the
City Treasurer the sum of money for which the company, corporation or
association represented by him or her is chargeable by virtue of the provisions
of this chapter.
(Ord. 24-O-2394, passed 9-4-2024)
§ 34.72 RECOVERY OF MONEY BY CITY.
   The sum of money for which such company, corporation or association is so
chargeable may be recovered of it, or its agents or agent, by an action in the
name of and for the use of the city as for money had and received. Nothing in
this section shall be held to exempt any person, corporation, company or
association from indictment and conviction under the provisions of an act
entitled "An Act to Enable Cities, Towns and Villages, Organized under Any
General or Special Law, to Levy and Collect a Tax or License Fee from Foreign
Insurance Companies for the Benefit of Organized Fire Departments", in force 7-
1-1895.
(Ord. 24-O-2394, passed 9-4-2024)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 35.001 REQUIREMENTS FOR EMPLOYMENT.
   (A)   All persons employed by the city shall first by subject to a physical
examination from a physician designated by the City Council, at city expense.
Such physician shall be furnished job requirements and employment will be
conditioned upon recommendation of the physician. Part-time employees for a
period of 30 workdays or less shall not be subject to this section.
   (B)   Each employee shall be a resident of the city prior to and during his
or her term of employment. Any variation of this condition shall be approved by
the majority of the Council.
   (C)   No person shall be hired under the age of 18.
   (D)   All persons must possess the necessary qualifications to perform the
duties of the position as established. No person shall be denied employment
because of race, color or creed.
(Prior Code, § 35.01)
§ 35.002 CLASSIFIED CITY SERVICE.
   (A)   All full-time officers and employees of the city, except the Mayor,
City Attorney, City Clerk, Comptroller and City Treasurer, shall be classified
and graded as follows:
