§ 39.01 PROPERTY ANNEXED MUST ANNEX TO PARK DISTRICT.
   As a condition to the passage of an ordinance annexing any property to bring
it within the city limits of the city, it is required that the petitioner or
petitioners for such annexation shall make application for annexation into the
city’s Park District and do whatever is necessary to bring about their
annexation of such property into the city’s Park District.
(Prior Code, § 39.01) (Ord. 572, passed - -1965)
§ 39.02 DISTURBANCE OF COUNTY RIGHTS-OF-WAY; INDEMNIFICATION AGREEMENT WITH
COUNTY.
   In consideration of waiver by the county of the insurance and surety bond
requirements or projects or activities which may be undertaken by the city
involving as disturbance of any right-of-way of the county within the corporate
limits of the city that it is agreed that:
   (A)   The city, or its successors, or assigns, shall indemnify and save
harmless the county, its officers, agents, employees and servants against all
loss, damage or expense that it or they may sustain as a result of any suit,
actions or claims of any character brought on account of property damage,
injury to or death of any person, or persons including persons performing any
work or activity under a permit issued by the county’s Highway Department which
any arise in connection with the work or activities to be performed under all
permits arising in any manner from the negligence or wrongful acts or failure
to act by the city and its employees in the performance of the work or
activity; and
   (B)   The city shall, at its own expense, appear, defend and pay all charges
of attorneys, costs and other expenses arising therefrom or incurred in
connection therewith, and, if any judgment shall be rendered against the county
in any such action, the city shall, at its own expense. Satisfy and the city
shall discharge the same.
(Prior Code, § 39.02) (Ord. 87-O-1269, passed 4-1-1987)
AFFIRMATIVE ACTION FOR UTILIZATION OF MINORITY BUSINESS ENTERPRISES
§ 39.15 ESTABLISHMENT OF PROGRAM.
   There is hereby established an Affirmative Action Program for the
Utilization of Minority Business Enterprises, and the Mayor is hereby directed
to implement the policies established in said programs.
(Prior Code, § 39.10) (Ord. 86-O-1240, passed 8-6-1986)
§ 39.16 SCOPE OF LEGISLATIVE ACT; INTENT.
   This subchapter and each of its terms shall be the effective legislative act
of a municipality without regard to whether such provisions should contain
terms contrary to the provision of current or subsequent nonpreemptive state
law, or legislate in a manner, or regarding a matter not delegated to
municipalities by state law. It is the intent of the corporate authorities of
the city that to the extent that the terms of this subchapter should be
inconsistent with any non-preemptive state law, that this subchapter shall
supersede state law in that regard within its jurisdiction.
(Prior Code, § 39.11) (Ord. 86-O-1240, passed 8-6-1986)
§ 39.17 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   MINORITY BUSINESS ENTERPRISE. A business enterprise in which 51% or more of
the investment capital is owned or controlled by members of minority groups.
   MINORITY GROUP. Women and any racial, religious or ethnic group which is a
minority within the Chicago metropolitan area, the members of which have been
hindered in their ability to engage in business enterprises because of racial,
religious, ethnic or sex discrimination. MINORITY GROUPS include Blacks,
Hispanics, American Indians and Oriental.
(Prior Code, § 39.12) (Ord. 86-O-1240, passed 8-6-1986)
§ 39.18 POLICY.
   It is the policy of the city that all contracts for the purchase by the city
of goods and/or services in excess of $2,500 shall contain the following
clause:
Contractor agrees that he shall actively solicit bids for the subcontracting of
goods or services from qualified minority business enterprises. At the request
of the city, contractor shall furnish evidence of his compliance with his
minority solicitation requirement. Contractor further agrees to consider the
grant of subcontractors to bidders who are minority business enterprises in a
light favorable to said minority enterprises where proposals are substantially
equal. Contractor further affirms that in obtaining his performance and bid
bonds, he will seek out and attempt to utilize companies which have records of,
and/or which will make commitments to, the bonding of minority contractors on a
rate basis comparable to their bonding of similar non-minority contractors. The
contractor may be required to submit this evidence as part of the bid or
subsequent to it. Contractor further agrees that 50% of its employees who
perform the contractor’s contractual obligations with the city shall be either
members of a minority group or residents of the city, unless such an agreement
would violate an applicable law, rule or regulation, or the Constitutions of
either the United States or the State of Illinois. For purposes of determining
whether the aforementioned not less than 50% standard has been met, employees
of subcontractors shall be considered employees of the contractor.
(Prior Code, § 39.13) (Ord. 86-O-1240, passed 8-6-1986)
§ 39.19 LISTS OF MINORITY BUSINESS ENTERPRISES TO BE KEPT.
   The purchasing agents of the city shall develop and maintain source lists of
minority business enterprises and shall include those applicable business
enterprises in solicitation of service and/or materials. Said list shall be
kept substantially current and shall include new business enterprises as the
occasion warrants. All other departments of the city involved in the
solicitation of services or materials shall utilize the aforesaid list on bid
solicitations. All departments of the city shall affirmatively and actively
seek the participation of minority business enterprises in procurement of goods
and services. Each department of the city shall submit a quarterly report on
the utilization of minority business enterprises to the office of the Mayor.
(Prior Code, § 39.14) (Ord. 86-O-1240, passed 8-6-1986)
§ 39.20 DESIGNATION OF SPECIFIC PROJECTS AND COMMODITIES FOR QUALIFIED MINORITY
BUSINESS ENTERPRISES.
   Consistent with all applicable laws, rules, regulations and the
Constitutions of the United States and the state, the Mayor shall, in
developing the work program and purchasing program of the city for each year,
designate specific projects and commodities which are to be preserved for
qualified minority business enterprises. Qualified business enterprises shall
be requested to submit proposals as to their cost of performing such contracts.
Upon approval of the annual budget, the Mayor shall meet with the appropriate
persons to determine those projects and commodities to be designated as reserve
for minority business enterprises. One of the considerations to be made by the
Mayor is the availability of competition among minority business enterprises in
the areas chosen. The Mayor shall not proceed with the program until the
Mayor’s designation of projects and commodities for minority business
enterprises is approved by the City Council as being consistent with city
policy and with all applicable laws, rules, regulations and the Constitutions
of the United States and the state. The results of each years program shall be
reported to the Council annually with recommendations for appropriate charges.
(Prior Code, § 39.15) (Ord. 86-O-1240, passed 8-6-1986)
§ 39.21 PERFORMANCE BOND.
   When the Mayor determines that the provisions of a performance bond which
would otherwise be required by any law, rule or regulation of the city or by
any state law, rules or regulation which does not preempt the power of
municipal units of local government is not needed to protect the city, and when
an alternative means of protecting the city in the performance of work is
available, a requirement of a performance bond shall not be included as part of
the bid specifications. It is the policy of the city that this procedure should
be utilized when it is determined that the requirement of a performance bond
would tend to discourage minority business enterprises form doing business with
the city.
(Prior Code, § 39.16) (Ord. 86-O-1240, passed 8-6-1986)
§ 39.22 ADMINISTRATIVE DEPARTMENTS TO PROVIDE ASSISTANCE.
   The administrative departments of the city shall cooperate with all
agencies, public and private, formed for the purpose of assisting minority
business enterprises to the extent necessary to complete studies and surveys of
the role and function of minority business enterprises. Said administrative
departments shall further give all necessary technical assistance to minority
business enterprises in the preparation and submission of bids for the
provision of goods and services.
(Prior Code, § 39.17) (Ord. 86-O-1240, passed 8-6-1986)
§ 39.23 RESPONSIBILITY FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF POLICY.
   The office of the Mayor of the city shall be charged with the responsibility
for implementation and procedural development of the policies set out in this
subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 39.18) (Ord. 86-O-1240, passed 8-6-1986)
SEXUAL HARASSMENT REPORTING PROCEDURE
§ 39.30 SEXUAL HARASSMENT REPORTING PROCEDURE.
   (A)   Pursuant to 5 ILCS 430/70-5 of the Act, elected city officials are
encouraged to promptly report claims of sexual harassment by another elected
official. Every effort should be made to file such complaints as soon as
possible, while facts are known, and potential witnesses are available. If the
elected official feels comfortable doing so, he or she should directly inform
the harassing individual that the individual's conduct or communication is
offensive and must stop.
   (B)   Elected officials should report claims of sexual harassment against an
Alderman to the Mayor or the City Clerk. If the report is made to the Mayor,
the Mayor shall promptly notify the City Clerk. If the Mayor is the subject of
the complaint, the City Clerk shall notify the most senior Alderman. The senior
Alderman is defined as the Alderman who was sworn into office on the earliest
date. If two or more aldermen were sworn into office on the same date,
seniority will be determined by alphabetical order of the Alderman's last name.
If the report is made to the City Clerk, the City Clerk shall promptly notify
the Mayor. If the City Clerk is the subject of the complaint, the Mayor shall
notify the most senior Alderman. Reports of sexual harassment will be
confidential to the greatest extent possible.
   (C)   When a complaint of sexual harassment is made against an elected
official, the Mayor shall appoint a qualified independent human resources
investigator, the Cook County Inspector General or, as a last resort, a law
firm that has experience in workplace investigations to conduct an independent
review of the allegations. If the allegations concern the Mayor, or the Mayor
is a witness or otherwise conflicted, the City Clerk shall make the
appointment. If the allegations concern both the Mayor and the City Clerk and/
or they are both witnesses or otherwise conflicted, the senior most Alderman
shall make the appointment. The investigator shall prepare a written report and
submit it to the Mayor and City Council.
   (D)   If the investigator finds that the elected official that is the
subject of the investigation has engaged in sexual harassment, the matter will
be addressed in accordance with the authority of the Board and the finding
shall be forwarded to the complainant and the Illinois Department of Human
Rights.
(Ord. 20-O-2259, passed 4-15-2020)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 50.001 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter shall be to regulate and control the
accumulation, removal and disposal of refuse, garbage and rubbish and to
eliminate unhealthy, unsanitary and unsightly conditions in the city.
(Prior Code, § 50.01) (Ord. 73-O-841, passed - -1973; Ord. 78-O-986, passed 6-
20-1978)
§ 50.002 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   GARBAGE. Rejected food wastes and includes every waste accumulation of
animal, fruit or vegetable matter used or intended for food, and such paper as
may necessarily be used for wrapping.
   REFUSE. All solid wastes of a community including garbage, ashes, rubbish,
dead animals, paper, sweepings and solid market and industrial wastes.
   RUBBISH. Such matter as ashes, cans, metalware, broken glass, crockery,
dirt, sweepings, boxes, wood, grass clippings or litter of any kind.
   SCAVENGER or REFUSE DISPOSAL CONTRACTOR. Any person, firm or corporation
engaged in the business of collecting and disposing of garbage, refuse and
rubbish.
(Prior Code, § 50.02) (Ord. 73-O-841, passed - -1973; Ord. 78-O-986, passed 6-
20-1978)
DISPOSAL AND COLLECTION
§ 50.015 ACCUMULATION OF GARBAGE ON PREMISES PROHIBITED.
   The owner, occupant and lessee of any premises in the city shall cause to be
removed from the premises all garbage, rubbish and refuse and shall keep the
premises at all times free and clean from any accumulation thereof.
(Prior Code, § 50.10) (Ord. 73-O-841, passed - -1973; Ord. 78-O-986, passed 6-
20-1978) Penalty, see §
50.999
§ 50.016 CONTAINERS; HOUSEHOLD; NON-HOUSEHOLD.
   (A)   Household container specifications. All household garbage, which shall
be drained and wrapped, and all household rubbish, excepting bulky rubbish such
as trees and branches, shall be stored in durable rust- resistant, non-
absorbent water-tight and easily washed containers which shall have covers.
Containers of the type intended to be emptied manually shall have adequate
handles or bales to facilitate collection and shall be not less than 20, nor
more than 30, gallons in capacity. Grass clippings and tree leaves may be
stored in plastic bags having a maximum capacity of four bushels.
   (B)   Non-household container specifications. All institutional, commercial
and industrial garbage shall be stored in durable, metal, rust-resisting or
corrosion-resistant, non-absorbent, water-tight and easily washable containers,
which shall have covers. Containers of the type intended to be emptied manually
shall have adequate handles or bales to facilitate collection, and shall be not
less than 20, nor more than 30, gallons in capacity. Grass clippings and tree
leaves may be stored in plastic bags having a minimum capacity of four bushels.
(Prior Code, § 50.11) (Ord. 73-O-841, passed - -1973; Ord. 78-O-986, passed 6-
20-1978)
§ 50.017 DISPOSAL OF GARBAGE IN STREETS AND PUBLIC PLACES PROHIBITED.
   It shall unlawful to dispose of or place any garbage or refuse in any street
or any other public place within the city, nor shall any person dispose of or
place any garbage, rubbish or refuse on private property, whether owned by such
person or not, within the limits of the city, unless the same shall be enclosed
in a suitable container or containers, for collection. A container shall be a
can of galvanized iron or non-corrosive material, rodent- proof, water-tight
and of the type commonly sold as a garbage can, of a suitable gauge and
construction to ensure durability.
(Prior Code, § 50.12) (Ord. 73-O-841, passed - -1973; Ord. 78-O-986, passed 6-
20-1978) Penalty, see §
50.999
§ 50.018 DISPOSAL OF WET GARBAGE.
   Each such occupant, person or tenant in possession shall cause all garbage
produced in or brought into such house, building or apartment, except that
disposed of by means of a garbage grinder, to be thoroughly drained of any
surplus liquid, securely wrapped and deposited in said container. All other
refuse or rubbish, as defined in §
50.002 of this chapter, may be deposited in such containers for collection.
(Prior Code, § 50.13) (Ord. 73-O-841, passed - -1973; Ord. 78-O-986, passed 6-
20-1978)
§ 50.019 DISPOSAL OF CARDBOARD CARTONS AND TREE CUTTINGS.
   (A)   Large cardboard cartons shall be broken down and bundled or tied
securely. Tree cuttings and branches shall be bundled securely in lengths not
to exceed four feet and heights to exceed two feet. The weight of any bundled
refuse shall not exceed 50 pounds.
   (B)   Beginning 12-1-2001, all grass clippings, leaves and yard waste shall
be placed in paper recycling bags or plastic garbage bags with a maximum 30-
gallon capacity. In order to be collected, a sticker must be affixed to each
bag which can be purchased at the city at a cost of $0.50 per sticker.
(Prior Code, § 50.14) (Ord. 73-O-841, passed - -1973; Ord. 78-O-986, passed 6-
20-1978; Ord. 01-O-1723, passed 10-17-2001) Penalty, see §
50.999
§ 50.020 COLLECTION; SCHEDULE; FREQUENCY; DUTY OF HOUSEHOLDS.
   (A)   (1)   All household garbage, refuse and rubbish shall be collected at
least once a week according to the following schedule and in accordance with
the following schedule. Collection of garbage, refuse and rubbish from
residential customers shall be completed on each day before the hour of 3:00
p.m. and shall be collected from various areas within the city in accordance
with the following schedule, to wit:
 
          From 159th Street south to 167th Street between Kedzie Parkway and
Monday    Dixie Highway and from 156th Place south to 159th Street between
          Dixie Highway and Western Avenue
Tuesday   From 159th Street south to 167th Street between Kedzie and the
          municipal boundary lying west of Crawford Avenue
Wednesday From 161st Street south to 167th Street between Dixie Highway and
          Park Avenue
          From 159th Street north to 155th Street between Central Park Avenue
          and Kedzie Avenue; from 159th Street north and east to Calitonia
          between Rockwell Street and Kedzie Avenue; and that portion of the
Thursday  city lying west of Interstate 57 east of Crawford Avenue, south of
          149th Street and north of 159th Street
          Or
          From 159th Street north between Rockwell on the east and Crawford on
          the west to the northern municipal city boundary
 
      (2)   All are as depicted on the map appended to the ordinance codified
herein as “Exhibit A”, which map is incorporated herein by reference and made a
part hereof as though fully set forth.
   (B)   It shall be mandatory for every household or other residential
establishment within the city to provide for the collection of such garbage,
refuse or rubbish and to place the same in proper containers for pickup by the
licensed scavenger or the city’s Department of Sanitation in accordance with
the schedule in this section.
   (C)   All institutional, commercial and industrial garbage and refuse shall
be collected daily, except Sunday; rubbish shall be collected at least weekly.
(Prior Code, § 50.15) (Ord. 73-O-841, passed - -1973; Ord. 78-O-986, passed 6-
20-1978; Ord.82-O-1088, passed 6-21-1982; Ord. 04-O-1786, passed 3-17-2004)
Penalty, see §
50.999
§ 50.021 RESTRICTIONS ON PLACEMENT OF CONTAINERS FOR PICKUP.
   (A)   (1)   It is unlawful to place containers or bundles of refuse on the
public rights-of-way for the purpose of pickup by commercial refuse haulers or
the city’s Department of Sanitation any earlier than 6:00 p.m. of the day
preceding the date of pickup.
      (2)   It is also unlawful to leave any empty containers upon the public
rights-of-way past the hour of 8:00 p.m. on the pickup day.
   (B)   It is unlawful to place or permit to be left upon the roadway any
containers or bundles at any time.
(Prior Code, § 50.16) (Ord. 73-O-841, passed - -1973; Ord. 78-O-986, passed 6-
20-1978) Penalty, see §
50.999
§ 50.022 SCAVENGER REGULATIONS.
   (A)   No person owning, driving or controlling the use of any vehicle used
for the carrying or transporting of any garbage, refuse or rubbish shall cause
or permit the vehicle, when in use for such purpose, to stand or remain before
or near any building or premises occupied by any person for an unreasonable or
unnecessary length of time. All scavenger vehicles shall be of the all-metal,
totally enclosed, packer type so that garbage, refuse or rubbish being carried
or transported on city streets will not be exposed and so that noxious fluids
will not leak out. Any person owning, driving or controlling such scavenger
vehicle shall cause all such vehicles to be thoroughly disinfected at least
once a week unless the same shall not have been used since the last
disinfection thereof. The vehicle or vehicles shall be subject to city
inspection from time to time.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a
scavenger, or collecting or removing garbage or offal, without first securing a
license therefor. Any person desiring such a license shall make application, in
writing, to the City Clerk in accordance with
Ch. 110 of this code of ordinances. All licenses issued to a scavenger or
refuse disposal contractor shall be for a period not to exceed one year
expiring on April 30 of each year.
   (C)   The annual license fee for a refuse disposal collector or scavenger
shall be $35 for one vehicle, plus $15 for each additional vehicle. The fee for
licenses issued after May 1 in any year shall be prorated over the period the
license will be in effect.
   (D)   (1)   All persons doing business as scavengers in the city must be
fully in compliance with all sections of this code of ordinances and ordinances
relating to the business, or relating to traffic or the movement of vehicles on
the streets.
      (2)   (a)   No license shall be issued under the provisions of this
subchapter unless the applicant for such license has first submitted proof of
insurance in the form of a certificate or memorandum of insurance issued by an
insurer duly authorized to issue such policies in the state; such insurance to
be written by a company acceptable to the City Council. Such certificate or
memorandum shall show that the applicant for a license has public liability
insurance covering his or her operation within the city, shall show the date of
expiration of such insurance and shall certify that the same shall not be
cancelled without at least ten days’ notice to the city. Upon cancellation or
expiration without renewal of such insurance, the license issued hereunder to
the insured shall be void.
         (b)   Such insurance shall be in the amount of not less than $100,000
for personal injuries including accidental death to any one person, in an
amount not less than $300,000 for each such accident and, as to property
damage, not less than $25,000 for each accident.
      (3)   No license shall be issued under the provisions of this subchapter
unless the applicant for such a license agrees to hold the city harmless from
any and all claims, damages or loss of use resulting from the applicant’s
business operations in the city. The insurance coverage shall include an
endorsement covering said “hold harmless” agreement in favor of the city.
      (4)   No license shall be issued under the provisions of this subchapter
unless the applicant files a performance bond with the sureties to be approved
by the Mayor and Council in the sum of $10,000 with the city as beneficiary,
conditioned upon the applicant continuing to properly operate the business of
scavenger for the period covered by the license in accordance with the
provisions of this code and to perform such collection and disposal services on
all accounts in accordance with provisions of this chapter. Upon cancellation
or expiration of such bond without replacement or renewal, the license issued
hereunder shall be void.
      (5)   No license shall be issued unless the applicant agrees to make
garbage and refuse collections in the areas and on the days as determined by
the city.
      (6)   Scavengers who contract for individual residential or commercial
(business) accounts for garbage, refuse and rubbish disposal and collection
shall service all such accounts not withstanding whether the account is paid in
full or not for at least 30 days after such account is delinquent; and, further
provided, they give notice to the city of all accounts, and all accounts
delinquent more than 30 days. Scavengers must notify the city of all changes in
accounts.
(Prior Code, § 50.17) (Ord. 73-O-841, passed - -1973; Ord. 78-O-986, passed 6-
20-1978) Penalty, see §
50.999
§ 50.023 CITY TO PROVIDE EXCLUSIVE SCAVENGER SERVICE FOR RESIDENTIAL PREMISES;
CONTAINERS.
   (A)   Effective 7-1-1982, the city shall be the only entity authorized to
provide scavenger services to and for single- and multiple-family residences
located within the corporate boundaries.
   (B)   Owners and occupants of each single- or multi-family dwelling within
the corporate boundaries shall be furnished with suitable containers for the
storage of garbage and refuse and the collection thereof by the city. Such
containers: shall be of a type, size and construction determined by the city;
shall be compatible with existing city equipment and procedures for the
collection of garbage and waste; and shall be provided by the city without
charge to the resident user thereof.
   (C)   Containers shall at all times remain the property of the city.
Residential users thereof shall be responsible to the city for damage to or
loss of such containers attributable to the negligence of, carelessness of or
willful acts of such resident users.
   (D)   No person, firm, organization, association, partnership, joint venture
or other entity, other than the city, shall engage in or undertake to provide
scavenger services to or for any residential structure or residential use
within the corporate boundaries of the city.
   (E)   No license shall henceforth be issued to any person, firm or entity
for the purpose of conducting a business of providing scavenger service to any
residential structure or use within the corporate boundaries of the city. Any
person, firm, corporation or other entity presently holding a current and valid
license to so operate shall be entitled, upon application to the city, to a
refund of moneys paid for such license, said refund to be prorated on a daily
basis from May 1 to July 1.
(Prior Code, § 50.18) (Ord. 82-O-1086, passed 5-17-1982) Penalty, see §
50.999
§ 50.024 RATES OF CHARGES FOR SERVICE; RESIDENTIAL; COMMERCIAL.
   (A)   The charge for residential garbage and refuse disposal services for
fiscal year 2021-2022 starting September 1, 2021 will be $25.81 which will be
due each month for each residence, and the cost for the yard waste stickers
will be $3.
   (B)   Spring clean-up shall be for one week during the month of May, at the
city’s discretion. During the clean-up week, all household trash will be
collected, including branch pick up. Branches must be separated from the
household trash and placed at the curb on the regularly scheduled garbage pick
up day during clean-up week. Cut trees will be picked up for a fee, to be
determined by the size (cubic yards). There shall be an additional charge for
trash collected in addition to the 90-gallon cart and two bags, up to four
cubic yards. Trash in excess of four cubic yards will not be collected without
city approval. Once approved, the excess trash will also be subject to an
additional charge. Charges for excess trash, bulk items and branches (outside
of clean-up week) shall be placed on the water account.
(Prior Code, § 50.19) (Ord. 85-O-1181, passed 6-22-1985; Ord. 87-O-1267, passed
3-18-1987; Ord. 94-O-1503, passed 7-20-1994; Ord. 97-O-1606, passed 5-7-1997;
Ord. 98-O-1650, passed 7-1-1998; Ord. 98-O-1655, passed 7-15-1998; Ord. 13-O-
2054, passed 4-24-2013; Ord. 19-O-2234, passed 6-19-2019; Ord. 21-O-2304,
passed 7-21-2021)
§ 50.025 SPECIAL COLLECTION OF BULKY ITEMS AND DEBRIS.
   (A)   (1)   There shall be certain days and times designated by the
Superintendent of the Department of Public Works in the spring and fall of the
year for the pick-up and disposal of bulky items and debris from residential
locations within the city at no additional charge.
      (2)   The designation of those dates and times shall be given the widest
possible publication and notice to the residents of the city.
   (B)   Residents may contact the Department of Public Works for the pick-up
of bulky items and debris from residential locations at times other than those
published dates and times in the spring and fall of the year; provided that,
payment of fees for such services in the amount of $15 for a one-half truck
load and $30 for a full truck load as may be estimated by the Superintendent of
Public Works as necessary to accomplish such task, is made not less than five
days in advance of the date of the requested service, to the city at the office
of the City Clerk.
(Prior Code, § 50.20) (Ord. 98-O-1647, passed 6-17-1998; Ord. 98-O-1655, passed
7-15-1998)
SPRING CLEANUP
§ 50.040 PURPOSE.
   For a two-week period in the spring season of each calendar year, there
shall be conducted in the city a spring cleanup for the purpose of encouraging
and assisting the residents of the city in their individual efforts to improve
the aesthetic appearance of their properties, thereby producing a beneficial
effect upon the city as a whole.
(Prior Code, § 50.30) (Ord. 75-O-894, passed - -1975)
§ 50.041 DETERMINATION OF DATE FOR SPRING CLEANUP.
   The dates during which the spring cleanup shall be conducted shall be
determined and established each year in such manner that the program may be
both compatible with other business of the city and conducted at such time that
appropriate weather conditions may be anticipated.
(Prior Code, § 50.31) (Ord. 75-O-894, passed - -1975)
§ 50.042 DISPOSAL OF TREE TRIMMINGS.
   During the course of the cleanup, the city shall arrange for the pickup and
disposal of accumulated tree trimmings and branches which have been deposited
at areas to be designated for such pickup and disposal.
(Prior Code, § 50.32) (Ord. 75-O-894, passed - -1975)
CITATIONS AND PAYMENT OF FINES
§ 50.055 WHEN CITATION ISSUED.
   Whenever a police officer is authorized to arrest a person without warrant
because of any violation of the provisions of this chapter, the police officer
may, in lieu of the filing of a complaint in court, in the first instance issue
to such alleged violator a citation, advising the person that he or she has
violated a specified provisions of this chapter or any applicable ordinance
requesting him or her to make payment in an amount applicable to the violation
as set forth in §
50.058 of this chapter as settlement of the violation claim and informing him
or her that, upon failure to so settle, a complaint will be filed in the
Circuit Court of the county, charging him or her with such violation.
(Prior Code, § 50.45) (Ord. 613, passed - -1966)
§ 50.056 SERVING NOTICE TO APPEAR.
   In the event that the person to whom the citation is issued fails to settle
and pay the violation claim within the prescribed time, or within a period of
time specified in a final notice, if one is served upon him or her, then the
peace officer is authorized to cause a notice to appear to be served upon the
alleged violator and is authorized to file a complaint and to prosecute the
same in the Circuit Court of the county.
(Prior Code, § 50.46) (Ord. 613, passed - -1966)
§ 50.057 PAYMENT BY VIOLATOR.
   (A)   Pursuant to the citation, the person so accused of the violation may
settle and compromise the violation claim in respect to the chapter or any
applicable ordinance violation by paying the municipality the applicable amount
as shown in the schedule set forth in §
50.058 of this chapter, within a period to be specified in the citation, not
more than seven days after the time the alleged offense was committed.
   (B)   Such payment shall be made in accordance with the instructions
contained in the citation, at the office of the Police Department, which shall
issue a receipt for the money so received and promptly remit the amount to the
City Treasurer to be credited to the proper municipal fund.
(Prior Code, § 50.47) (Ord. 613, passed - -1966)
§ 50.058 FEE FOR VIOLATION; NON-PAYMENT OF FINE.
   The violation claim described in the citation to be issued pursuant to the
terms of this chapter may be settled, compromised and paid in the respective
amounts set forth in the following schedule.
   (A)   In the event that the payment is made prior to the mailing by the
municipality or by the peace officer of a final notice, $5 shall be accepted as
settlement.
   (B)   In the event that payment has not be paid prior to the mailing of a
final notice and, in fact, final notice has been mailed, $7 shall be accepted
as settlement.
   (C)   In the event that payment is not made within the time prescribed in
the final notice, and a notice to appear has been served and a complaint filed
in the Circuit Court of the county, payment of any fine and costs shall be in
such amounts as may be determined and established by the Circuit Court of the
county.
(Prior Code, § 50.48) (Ord. 613, passed - -1966; Ord. 69-O-705, passed - -1969)
ENFORCEMENT
§ 50.070 ENFORCEMENT BY HEALTH OFFICER.
   The Health Officer shall notify anyone who violates the provisions of this
chapter in writing to such person directing him or her to cease and desist with
respect to such violation. Should the condition continue to exist the Health
Officer shall issue a citation or summons to such violator. Should the
violation still exist, the Health Officer shall cause a complaint to be sworn
to and warrant to be issued for such violation.
(Prior Code, § 50.60) (Ord. 73-O-841, passed - -1973; Ord. 78-O-986, passed 6-
20-1978)
§ 50.071 REMOVAL OF GARBAGE BY CITY; NOTICE; LIEN.
   (A)   The Health Officer, knowing a health hazard exists due to uncollected
garbage, refuse or rubbish, shall report same to the Mayor who, after giving
notice to the violator to remove such garbage, refuse or rubbish, may cause the
city to remove and collect such garbage, refuse or rubbish from the property by
the use of city vehicles and city employees, or by an agreement with a licensed
scavenger.
   (B)   The costs for such services rendered in the collection and cleanup and
disposal of such garbage, refuse or rubbish shall constitute a lien on the real
estate operated as provided by statute, superior to all subsequent liens and
encumbrances, except tax liens, if within 60 days after such cost and expense
are incurred the city or person performing the service by authority of the
city, in his or its own name, files notice of lien in the office of the
Recorder of Deeds of the county or in the office of the Registrar of Title of
the county if the real estate affected is registered under the Torrens system.
   (C)   The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out a
description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof, the
amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the
service and the date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the
city.
   (D)   However, the lien of such city shall not be valid as to any purchaser
whose rights in and to such real estate have arisen subsequent to removal of
the garbage and debris and prior to the filing of such notice, and the lien of
such city shall not be valid as to any mortgagee, judgment creditor or other
lienor whose rights in and to such real estate arise prior to the filing of
such notice.
   (E)   Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner of or persons
interested in such property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall
be released by the city or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the
release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien.
   (F)   The lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose as in the case of
mortgages or mechanics’ liens. Suit to foreclose this lien shall be commenced
within two years after the date of filing notice of lien.
(Prior Code, § 50.61) (Ord. 73-O-841, passed - -1973; Ord. 78-O-986, passed 6-
20-1978)
§ 50.072 SUIT AT LAW.
   Nothing in this chapter shall preclude the city from filing an action in a
suit at law for total costs and expenses incurred for the removal of garbage,
refuse and rubbish against any person.
(Prior Code, § 50.62) (Ord. 73-O-841, passed - -1973; Ord. 78-O-986, passed 6-
20-1978)
§ 50.073 IMPLEMENTATIONS.
   (A)   There is created a standing committee of five members composed of
three Council members and two members of the public, to be appointed by the
Mayor upon the advice and consent of the City Council, to meet monthly and
review all problems arising in the city with respect to the subject matter of
this chapter with the duty to make further recommendations to the Council and
with the purpose of eliminating unhealthy, unsanitary and unsightly conditions
in the city.
   (B)   The Health Officer of the city shall serve as an ex officio member of
the committee.
(Prior Code, § 50.63) (Ord. 73-O-841, passed - -1973; Ord. 78-O-986, passed 6-
20-1978)
ILLEGAL DISPOSAL OF GARBAGE
§ 50.085 ILLEGAL DISPOSAL OF GARBAGE ON STREETS OR PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of garbage, materials, refuse
or abandoned vehicles or materials on, upon or about any public street, way or
place of upon any private property in or near (within 150 feet of) the
corporate limits of the city at any time.
(Prior Code, § 50.70) (Ord. 02-O-1733, passed 4-17-2002) Penalty, see §
50.999
§ 50.086 USE OF MOTOR VEHICLES IN ILLEGAL DISPOSAL OF GARBAGE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, partnership or other entity to
utilize a motor vehicle in the illegal disposal of garbage, materials, refuse
or abandoned vehicles or materials on, upon or about any public street, way or
place or upon any private property in the city.
(Prior Code, § 50.71) (Ord. 02-O-1733, passed 4-17-2002) Penalty, see §
50.999
§ 50.087 TOWING AND FORFEITURE OF MOTOR VEHICLES USED IN ILLEGAL DISPOSAL.
   Each person enforcing the provisions of this subchapter is hereby authorized
and directed to forthwith seize and tow such motor vehicle, as an abandoned
vehicle, as may have been used in the illegal dumping of garbage pursuant to
this subchapter and pursuant to the provisions of Ch. 90 of this code of
ordinances and of the forfeiture provisions of the state’s Motor Vehicle Act,
being 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.
(Prior Code, § 50.72) (Ord. 02-O-1733, passed 4-17-2002) Penalty, see §
50.999
§ 50.088 ENFORCEMENT.
   This chapter may be enforced by any sworn member of the city’s Police
Department, Fire Department, Director of Building and Housing, Ordinance
Enforcement Officer and such other person as may be specially charged by the
Mayor with the duty to enforce this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 50.73) (Ord. 02-O-1733, passed 4-17-2002)
§ 50.999 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this
chapter, for which another penalty is not provided, shall be fined not less
than $10, nor more than $500 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be
deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
   (B)   The penalty for the violation of the provisions of §
50.017 of this chapter shall be set forth in this section; except that, the
minimum fine shall be $2,000 and the maximum fine shall be $5,000.
   (C)   Violation of the terms and provisions of §
50.023 of this chapter shall be punishable by fine not to exceed $500. For the
purpose of enforcement of §
50.023 of this chapter, each separate instance of unauthorized and prohibitive
provision of scavenger service to a residence or residential use within the
city, or each day of failure or refusal to utilize a container to be provided
by the city for each residential user shall constitute a separate offense.
   (D)   The penalty for the violation of §§
50.085 through
50.088 of this chapter shall be as set forth division (A) above; except that,
the minimum and maximum fine shall be $500.
(Prior Code, § 50.99) (Ord. 73-O-841, passed - -1973; Ord. 78-O-986, passed 6-
20-1978; Ord. 82-O-1086, passed 5-17-1982; Ord. 02-O-1733, passed 4-17-2002)
