AMUSEMENTS
§ 113.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   AMUSEMENT. Includes fortune telling, palmistry, astrology and theatrical
exhibitions, movie theaters, pool halls, bowling alleys, roller-skating rinks,
ice-skating rinks, shows and similar entertainment offered, operated, presented
or exhibited for gain or admission for which the public is required to a pay a
fee.
   PLACE. Theater, auditorium, hall, park, grounds, gardens, tent or other
enclosure or area within which it is intended to produce, offer or present any
amusement.
(Prior Code, § 113.01) (Ord. 71-O-787, passed - -1971; Ord. 24-O-2388, passed
5-15-2024)
§ 113.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to conduct or
operate any amusement which is open to the public without first obtaining a
license to do so.
   (B)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to those amusements or
amusement devices which are specifically licensed by any other provision of
this code.
(Prior Code, § 113.02) (Ord. 71-O-787, passed - -1971; Ord. 24-O-2388, passed
5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.03 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Applications for a license shall be in compliance with the general ordinance
provisions relating to licenses as set forth in
Ch. 110 of this code of ordinances.
(Prior Code, § 113.03) (Ord. 71-O-787, passed - -1971; Ord. 24-O-2388, passed
5-15-2024)
§ 113.04 LICENSE FEE.
   (A)   The annual license fee for an amusement license shall be as set forth
in the Business License Fees Ordinance.
   (B)   The City Council is empowered to exempt from payment of a license fee
any charitable, school or church function wherein the proceeds of the function
are being raised for a charitable or public purpose.
(Prior Code, § 113.04) (Ord. 71-O-787, passed - -1971; Ord. 24-O-2388, passed
5-15-2024)
VIDEO GAMING TERMINALS
§ 113.10 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   TERMINAL OPERATOR. Any individual, partnership, corporation or limited
liability company that is licensed by the State of Illinois and that owns,
services and maintains video gaming terminals for placement in licensed
establishments, licensed truck stop establishments, licensed fraternal
establishments, or licensed veterans establishments.
   VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL. Any electronic video game machine that, upon
insertion of cash, electronic cards or vouchers, or any combination thereof, is
available to play or simulate the play of a video game, including but not
limited to video poker, line up, and blackjack, as authorized by the Illinois
Gaming Board utilizing a video display and microprocessors in which the player
may receive free games or credits that can be redeemed for cash. The term does
not include a machine that directly dispenses coins, cash, or tokens or is for
amusement purposes only.
   LICENSED LOCATION. Any licensed establishment, licensed fraternal
establishment, licensed veterans establishment, licensed truck stop
establishment or licensed large truck stop establishment as defined by the
Video Gaming Act. Additionally, the definitions enumerated in the Video Gaming
Act, 230 ILCS 40/5, are adopted herein.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 113.11 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No business establishment shall operate, permit to be operated, keep or
maintain any video gaming terminal in the city without first having obtained a
video gaming license from the city. Each video gaming terminal shall have a
license. Each license issued shall be for a period of one calendar year
beginning May 1 and ending April 30 and is the responsibility of the business
license holder.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.12 APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS.
   A video gaming terminal license must be applied for by the owner of the
establishment so designated and licensed by the state's Gaming Board allowing
such establishment to operate video gaming terminals.
   (A)   In addition to the application requirements of Chapter 110 of this
code, applications for a video gaming license shall include:
      (1)   The name and addresses of the business establishment where the
device is to be used;
      (2)   A general description of the proposed device;
      (3)   The number of other coin operated amusement devices and/or video
gaming terminals proposed for the same address;
      (4)   The name and address of the owner of the video gaming terminals;
      (5)   A copy of the location license issued by the Illinois Gaming Board;
and
      (6)   Any other information the Director of Building and Housing deems
necessary to process the application.
   (B)   The annual license fee for each video gaming terminal shall be as
specified in the Business License Fees Ordinance and shall be split equally
between the licensed location and the terminal operator.
   (C)   The city shall have the authority to make and publish reasonable rules
and regulations consistent with this subchapter and other laws of the city and
the state for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this
subchapter.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 113.13 RESTRICTIONS.
   It is unlawful for any person or business within the city to:
   (A)   Keep, install or use a video gaming terminal without a state license.
   (B)   Keep, install or use a video gaming terminal without a city license.
   (C)   Fail to prominently display a current city license sticker with an
assigned number on each video gaming terminal.
   (D)   Keep, install or use a greater number of video gaming terminals than
that specified in the Video Gaming Act.
   (E)   Fail to comply with all provisions of the Video Gaming Act.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
113.99
DONATION CONTAINERS
§ 113.20 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DONATION CONTAINER. Any box, bin, trailer, vehicle, structure or other
receptacle that is intended or used as a collection point for donated clothing,
shoes, books, or other household items at times when no employee or
representative of the sponsoring company or organization is present.
   APPLICANT. The organization or company benefitting from the donation
container or the host site on whose property the donation container is
situated.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 113.21 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful for any person to place a donation container within the city
without first obtaining a license therefore from the Building and Housing
Department. The fee shall be as specified in the Business License Fees
Ordinance.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.22 REGULATIONS.
   (A)   The applicant shall indicate the following information on the donation
container: the name of organization or company, address and contact telephone
number.
   (B)   All signage on a donation container shall be in compliance with all
requirements contained in this code.
   (C)   A donation container shall be painted and in good condition and
appearance, with no structural damage, no holes in the receptacle that would
allow leaks, no visible rust and free of graffiti or advertising other than the
name of the host site or organization or company benefitting from a donation
container.
   (D)   A donation container shall only be used as a collection receptacle for
clothing, books, or other household items.
   (E)   The collection or storage of items on top of, outside of, or next to
the donation container is prohibited.
   (F)   All donation containers must be located inside a fully enclosed
principal structure. Donation containers may not be placed outside a fully
enclosed and principal structure on any lot.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.23 ENFORCEMENT.
   (A)   The organization or company benefitting from the donation container
and the host site on whose property the donation container is situated are
jointly and severally liable for the maintenance, upkeep and servicing of a
donation container.
   (B)   Failure to maintain, upkeep or service a donation container shall
result in citations and fines as specified herein.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
SELF SERVICE DEVICES AND MACHINES
§ 113.30 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   SELF-SERVICE DEVICES AND MACHINES. Any device or machine that provides goods
or a service without the need for personal assistance in exchange for the
payment of funds, whether through credit card terminal, coin or cash dispenser.
SELF SERVICE DEVICES AND MACHINES shall include but not be limited to automatic
teller machines (ATMs), air pumps, charging stations, electronic games,
amusement devices, pay phones, newspaper machines, jukeboxes, pinball machines,
SELF SERVICE DEVICES AND MACHINES does not include those devices or machines
that serve food or drinks or video gaming terminals as defined in the Video
Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et. seq.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 113.31 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (A)   No person shall keep, install, maintain, operate, service, lease or
distribute any self- service device or machine upon any premises within the
city for use by the public without first having obtained a license therefor.
   (B)   The license fee to be paid by an operator or proprietor to the city
shall be per device or machine as specified in the Business License Fees
Ordinance.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.32 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Any person desiring a license shall make application therefor to the
Building and Housing Department pursuant to the application provisions of
Chapter 110. The application shall include the type and owners of the machines
or devices, the address of the premises where the licensed device or devices
are to be operated, the trade name and a general description of the device or
devices to be licensed, the name of the manufacturer and the serial number.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 113.33 ELIGIBILITY FOR LICENSE.
   No person shall be eligible for a license if its owners, stockholders,
managers, members employees or any of them have employed coercive or illegal
measures to promote the use of his or her machines.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 113.34 REGULATIONS.
   All self service devices and machines shall be maintained in proper working
order and shall not operate as to create a nuisance to surrounding buildings
and persons.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.35 SUBCHAPTER TO BE IN ADDITION TO OTHER PROVISIONS.
   The requirement of this subchapter shall be in addition to and not in
substitution of the terms and provisions of this code or of any applicable
ordinance of the city requiring the purchase of a license or sticker for each
coin-operated machine kept or maintained for use by the public.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 113.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
110.99 of this code of ordinances.
   (B)   Tickets may be issued to the licensed location and the terminal
operator.
   (C)   Any person, firm or corporation violating any section of this chapter
shall be fined no more than $200 for each offense. Each day that a violation
continues shall be considered a separate offense. Nothing in this chapter shall
be deemed to limit the city in any way to use any or all other means available
to remove a nuisance, or summarily eliminate immediate hazards to the public
health, safety or welfare.
(Prior Code, § 113.99) (Ord. 67-O-673, passed - -1967; Ord. 84-O-1145, passed
4-2-1984; Ord. 84-O-1161, passed 12-17-1984; Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
CHAPTER 114: FOOD SERVICE BUSINESS
Section
Food Service Business
   
114.001   Definitions

FOOD SERVICE BUSINESS
§ 114.001 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   COFFEE SHOP. Any establishment where drinks and small food items can be
purchased for consumption on or off site. COFFEE SHOPS include bakeries, juice
and smoothie bars.
   EMPLOYEE. Any person working on the premises of a food service establishment
who engages in food preparation or service, or who comes in contact with any
food utensil or equipment.
   EQUIPMENT. All stoves, ranges, hoods, meatblocks, tables and similar items,
other than utensils, used in the operation of a food service establishment.
   FOOD SERVICE BUSINESS. Any place at which or in which food is sold or
offered for sale to the general public for consumption on or off the premises.
“Restaurants”, “coffee shops”, “food peddlers” and “grocery stores” shall be
considered food service establishments.
   FOOD PEDDLER. Any person who sells or offers for sale any food items from a
non-motorized cart or stand.
   FOOD. Any raw, cooked or processed edible substance, beverage or ingredient
used or intended for use in whole or in part for human consumption.
   GROCERY STORE. Any establishment where fresh or packaged foods are sold for
consumption off site. GROCERY STORE includes convenience stores, fruit stores,
delis, butchers and meat markets but does not include packaged liquor stores
licensed under the establishments selling only packaged liquor and licensed
under Chapter 112 of this code.
   HEALTH OFFICER. The Health Officer of the city or his or her authorized
representative.
   RESTAURANT. Any establishment where meals can be purchased by the general
public for consumption on or off site.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023; Ord. 25-O-2412, passed 7-16-2025)
§ 114.002 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful for any person to operate a food service business without
first obtaining a license to do so. A separate license is required for each
food service establishment.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 114.003 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Applications for such license shall be in compliance with the general
ordinance provisions relating to licenses as set forth in
Chapter 110 of this code of ordinances.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)
§ 114.004 INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   In addition to other inspections required by this code or any other
applicable ordinance of the city, upon receipt of the application, together
with the required license fees, the Health Officer shall make an inspection of
the food service business.
   (B)   The Health Officer shall inspect each food service business at least
annually, and shall make as many additional inspections and reinspections as
shall be necessary for the enforcement of this subchapter.
   (C)   The Health Officer, after proper identification, shall be permitted to
enter, at any reasonable time, any food service business for the purpose of
making inspections to determine compliance with this subchapter.
   (D)   The Health Officer shall be permitted to examine the records of the
establishment to obtain pertinent information pertaining to food and supplies
and to persons employed.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)
§ 114.005 LICENSE FEE.
   The annual license fee for each food service establishment shall be as
specified in the Business License Fees Ordinance.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)
§ 114.006 SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   No person whose food service business license has been revoked shall be
entitled to apply for another food service business license for the same
location for a period of six months from the date of revocation.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)
§ 114.007 REGULATIONS.
   All food service establishments shall obtain and maintain all required
county, state and federal licensure for food service and handling and shall
comply with all applicable laws thereto.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 114.008 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   The City Council shall have the right to determine the hours of operation
for each license issued under the terms of this subchapter.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)
VENDING MACHINES
§ 114.020 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   VENDING MACHINE. Any machine or device from which or through the operation
of which bottled soft drinks, packaged candy or other packaged food is sold to
the general public for human consumption.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)
§ 114.021 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall maintain, keep or operate a vending machine as defined above
without having first obtained a vending license and a separate license for each
vending machine.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 114.022 PERIODIC INSPECTIONS.
   The Health Officer shall from time to time inspect or cause to be inspected
each vending machine and the storage of articles thereby dispensed, for the
purpose of ascertaining whether the provisions of this code and all applicable
laws of the state are being complied with.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)
§ 114.023 SANITARY REGULATIONS.
   (A)   All food which is received, stored and displayed for dispersal from a
vending machine shall be adequately protected from dust, flies, insects, vermin
or any contamination.
   (B)   All vending equipment and parts thereof with which food is liable to
be in direct contact shall be kept clean and free from dust, dirt, insects and
other contaminating materials.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)
MOBILE FOOD VEHICLES
§ 114.030 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BEVERAGES. A liquid for drinking that does not contain alcohol.
   FOOD or FOODSTUFF. Any substance that is defined as a raw, cooked, or
processed edible substance, ice, beverage, an ingredient used or intended for
use or for sale in whole or in part for human consumption, and chewing gum.
   FOOD DELIVERY VEHICLE. Any vehicle that is primarily used for the delivery
of food or beverages to consumers in the city, on request for such delivery,
but does not include vehicles that primarily make deliveries of supplies or
inventory to licensed food establishments, food stores, or mobile food service
establishments.
   FOOD PREPARATION. Packaging, processing, cooking, assembling, portioning, or
any operation that changes the form, flavor, or consistency of food, but does
not include trimming of produce.
   MOBILE FOOD VEHICLE. A licensed, motorized vehicle modified to include
facilities for the cooking, processing and preparation of food and beverages,
when temporarily parked on property other than a public street, road, or right-
of-way, and from which food items or beverages are then sold to the general
public.
   MOBILE FOOD VENDOR. The owner or vendor of a mobile food vehicle to be
licensed under this chapter, and who shall be the party responsible for the
compliance of the operations of the mobile food vehicle with the requirements
of this chapter, the city code, and other applicable laws and regulations.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)
§ 114.031 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale any candy, ice cream,
confections, or any food or beverage for human consumption from any motor
vehicle or any vehicle or any vehicle or cart of any kind in the city unless
the mobile food vehicle is properly licensed. All mobile food vehicle licenses
are subject to the approval by the Mayor and the City Council.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 114.032 COMPLIANCE WITH STATE AND LOCAL LAWS.
   Each mobile food vehicle that is permitted to operate in the city shall be
operated in strict compliance with the regulations set forth in this chapter as
well as all applicable ordinances, laws, rules, and regulations, including
without limitation, all zoning, building, health, fire, and safety regulations,
and all other provisions of this code, the county code, and state law. If a
conflict arises between applicable regulations, the strictest regulation shall
control.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 114.033 APPLICATION.
   (A)   Applications for all mobile food vehicle licenses shall be made in
writing to the Building and Housing Department on forms provided by that
office. In addition to the application requirements of Chapter 110 of this
code, each application shall include the following:
      (1)   The vendor shall, with its application for a license, register or
cause to be registered the mobile food vehicle operated by, or operated for,
such vendor within the city. The following information for the mobile food
vehicle to be registered shall be provided:
         (a)   The year, make, model, color, license plate number and vehicle
identification number of the vehicle; and
         (b)   The name, address and telephone number of the owner of the
vehicle.
      (2)   A description of the food product(s) offered for sale, including
the intended menu;
      (3)   The name and address of the food preparation establishment or food
establishment where food items are to be prepared and/or packaged for sale by
mobile food vendor from the mobile food vehicle with copies of the
establishments most recent health inspection report from the local health
jurisdiction and County Health Department permits, and copies of the same
documentation with respect to the mobile food vehicle and/or mobile food
vendor;
      (4)   A letter of agreement from the food preparation establishment or
food service establishment where food items are prepared and/or packaged for
sale by the vendor from the mobile food vehicle agreeing to comply with all
applicable laws and regulations;
      (5)   A list of locations and times the mobile food vehicle will be
conducting its operations within the city, which may be amended from time to
time by the mobile food vendor to reflect its then current operations of the
mobile food vehicle, subject to review and approval by the Building and Housing
Department;
      (6)   Copies of all necessary licenses or permits required by the State
Public Health or Transportation authorities for the operation of the mobile
food vehicle;
      (7)   The written consent of the property owner stating the mobile food
vehicle is allowed to operate on the property, together with copies of any
relevant documentation between the property owner and the mobile food vendor
evidencing the terms of such consent;
      (8)   A signed statement approved by the city as to form and substance
providing that the vendor shall hold harmless the city and its officers and
employees, and shall indemnify the city, its officers, and employees for any
claims for damage to property or injury to persons which may be occasioned by
any activity carried out under the terms of the license; and
      (9)   Proof of insurance as follows:
         (a)   Commercial general liability insurance coverage insuring the
vendor and the city with respect to occurrences arising out of the activities
authorized by the license, with such coverage having combined single limits of
not less than $1,000,000 for personal injury and death and property damage per
occurrence, and in the aggregate, which coverage shall specifically refer to
this license. Coverage of the city shall be by written endorsement naming the
city as an additional insured.
         (b)   Automobile liability insurance with coverage of not less than
$1,000,000 for personal injuries or death per occurrence and $1,000,000 for
property damage per occurrence. All insurance coverage provided under the
license shall expressly provide that it is primary and noncontributory to any
insurance coverage maintained by the city, and shall waive any rights of
recovery against the city.
         (c)   Copies of all policies of insurance, certificates of insurance
and endorsements reflecting the coverages required under this agreement shall
be provided to the city prior to the issuance of any license under this
chapter. All such insurance coverage shall further provide that it may not be
cancelled except upon 30 days written notice served upon the Mayor and his or
her designee. A license issued pursuant to the provisions of this section shall
be invalid at any time the insurance required in this subchapter is not
maintained and evidence of continuing coverage is not filed with the Building
and Housing Department.
   (B)   At the time of application, all applicants shall pay an application
fee and corresponding inspection fees for building and fire to the Building and
Housing Department.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)
§ 114.034 OPERATING LOCATIONS.
   (A)   Mobile food vehicles are authorized to operate only in the following
locations in city:
      (1)   The Amazon fulfillment warehouse property located at 2201 W. 159th
Street, with the permission of the property owner;
      (2)   The parking lot located at the northeast corner of 16 7th Street
and Dixie Highway;
      (3)   The Cook County Courthouse Sixth Municipal District property
located at 16501 S. Kedzie Avenue; and
      (4)   All other locations require prior approval of the City Council.
   (B)   In addition to the above restrictions, no mobile food vehicle shall
operate in a location that:
      (1)   Would substantially obstruct a public way;
      (2)   Would impair the movement of pedestrians or vehicles;
      (3)   Would pose a hazard to public safety;
      (4)   Is adjacent to a bus stop, taxi stand or handicap loading zone;
      (5)   Is directly in front of a property entryway;
      (6)   Is adjacent to or within 500 feet of the property line of a food
establishment business. This requirement may be waived if the application is
submitted with written consent of the proprietor of the adjacent food
establishment business; or
      (7)   Is within 500 feet of any festival, special event, or civic event
that is permitted or sponsored by the city except when the vendor has obtained
a temporary vendor permit from the city;
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 114.035 REGULATIONS.
   All mobile food vehicles are subject to the following regulations:
   (A)   Mobile food vehicles must be brought to a complete stop, with the
ignition turned off, and be lawfully parked within the location approved for
the license prior to commencing operations.
   (B)   Pedestrian walkways of not less than six feet must be maintained
around the mobile food vehicle location.
   (C)   No more than three mobile food vehicles shall be allowed to operate
per private parking lot located in the authorized locations. The private
parking lot must remain in compliance with the zoning code, including the off-
street parking requirements for the host parking lot. The mobile food vehicles
shall not block required drive aisles and must be parked on an all-weather
surface lot at all times.
   (D)   A vendor shall not operate on private property within the permitted
operating locations without first obtaining written consent to operate from the
affected private property owner.
   (E)   Mobile food vehicles may not operate within the city for more than
eight hours during any 24-hour period, but in no case to exceed the hours of
operation for the business on the property on which the mobile food vehicle is
located.
   (F)   All mobile food vehicle vehicles shall have an annual inspection by
the Health Inspector and Fire Department.
   (G)   If liquid propane gas is used, the following conditions shall be met:
      (1)   Cooking and warming equipment shall be in good working condition
and cleaned of grease or other combustible material.
      (2)   Portable liquid propane gas containers, piping, valves and fittings
which are located outside and are being used to fuel equipment shall be
adequately protected to prevent tampering, damage by vehicles or other hazards,
and shall be located in an approved location. Portable liquid gas containers
shall be securely fastened in place by use of an approved method to prevent
unauthorized movement, tipping or regulator damage.
      (3)   Fittings, valves and hoses used with liquid propane gas equipment
shall be maintained in good working condition. When, in the opinion of the Fire
Safety Official, an unsafe condition exists with the fitting, valve, or hose
used by the equipment, it shall be replaced or the equipment shall not be used.
      (4)   Liquid propane gas containers shall be stored within a suitable
enclosure or otherwise protected against tampering.
      (5)   A Type I hood shall be installed at or above all commercial cooking
appliances and domestic cooling appliances used for commercial purposes that
produce grease laden vapors.
      (6)   Combustible materials shall be kept a minimum of three feet from
cooking appliances.
      (7)   A fire extinguisher of minimum size 2A10BC shall be provided in the
cooking area. Cooking equipment involving vegetable or animal oils and fats
shall be protected by a Class K rated portable fire extinguisher.
   (H)   Mobile food vehicles must provide or have garbage receptacles readily
available for immediate use by customers of the mobile food vehicle. City trash
receptacles are not to be used for this purpose. Such receptacles shall be
removed from the site upon the conclusion of the mobile food vehicle
operations, and at all times when the mobile food vehicle is not at the
location for which the license has been approved.
   (I)   Vendors must pick up, remove, and dispose of all garbage, refuse, or
litter consisting of foodstuffs, wrappers, and/or materials at one time
dispensed from the mobile food vehicle, and any residue deposited on the street
from the operation thereof, and shall otherwise maintain in a clean and debris-
free condition the entire area within a 25 foot radius of the location where
the mobile food vehicle is operating.
   (J)   Mobile food vehicles must comply with all noise regulations of the
city.
   (K)   Mobile food vehicles may not provide seating or tables for their
customers.
   (L)   Mobile food vehicles are allowed to display signage that is painted or
permanently affixed to the vehicle or freestanding sandwich boards.
   (M)   Mobile food vehicles may not have amplified sound or music emanating
from the vehicle.
   (N)   Mobile food vehicles shall be parked on all-weather surface, asphalt
or concrete, as determined by the §
156.313 of this code of ordinances, for the duration of their operation.
   (O)   Mobile food vehicles shall not be allowed to park in fire lanes,
handicap parking spaces, or in any other location that will impede traffic flow
or create unsafe conditions for pedestrians.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 114.036 LICENSE FEE.
   The annual license fee for each mobile food vehicle shall be as specified in
the Business License Fees Ordinance.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)
§ 114.037 CONSENT OF PROPERTY OWNER REQUIRED.
   A mobile food vehicle may not serve, dispense, or sell food or beverages in
a public or private parking lot within the corporate limits of the city without
having first obtained written consent to operate from the owner of the property
on which the lot is located. A copy of such written consent shall be maintained
in the mobile food vehicle for review on request by any city employee or
officer and provided to the Building and Housing Department.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 114.038 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   (A)   A mobile food vehicle may be open to the public only between the hours
of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., Monday through Friday.
   (B)   Daily set up of a mobile food vehicle may not occur before one hour
prior to the permitted opening time, and the end of the day, clean up must be
completed not later than 6:30 p.m.
   (C)   Mobile food vehicles shall not be parked on the premises from which
they operate under license during the time period after end of the day clean up
and before the permitted set up time on the next intended day of operation.
   (D)   Hours of operation beyond these specified hours for special events
conducted by an owner or occupant of the location proposed for the operation of
the mobile food vehicle may be authorized with prior approval from the City
Council, upon verification that the conduct of the proposed event otherwise
complies with the applicable ordinances of the city, and the laws and
regulations of any other governmental authorities having jurisdiction.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)
§ 114.039 SIGNAGE FURNISHING AND FIXTURES.
   It shall be unlawful for a vendor to use or cause to be displayed while in
transit, motion or parked any flashing or electronic signs or illuminated
signs. It shall be unlawful for mobile food vehicles to display or utilize any
signage that is not permanently affixed to a mobile food unit.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 114.040 CONSUMPTION OF ALCOHOL PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any mobile food vehicle and mobile food vendor to
sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor on the licensed premises, or to allow
patrons to consume liquor on the licensed premises regardless of whether such
liquor is provided by a licensee, a patron or otherwise, whether for a fee or
otherwise, without first having been issued an appropriate retail liquor
license in conformity with
Chapter 112 of this code of ordinances.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 114.041 DENIAL OF LICENSE.
   An applicant may be denied a mobile food vehicle license under any of the
following conditions:
   (A)   The applicant has previously failed to comply with the provisions of a
mobile food vehicle license;
   (B)   The applicant has been convicted of a violation of any provisions of
this chapter; or
   (C)   The applicant has failed to qualify for any other license required by
the code of ordinances of the city.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)
§ 114.042 EXEMPTIONS; SCOPE.
   Food delivery vehicles shall be exempt from the application of this chapter.
The regulations of this subchapter shall only apply to the mobile food vendors
in connection with their operation of mobile food vehicles, as defined in this
subchapter.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)
§ 114.043 LICENSE TO BE DISPLAYED.
   Upon issuance of a mobile food vehicle license, the operator shall, at all
times, when operating a mobile food vehicle in the city, display the license
that has been issued by the city that will include the license number and year
for which the license is valid. The mobile food vendor shall display this
license upon the request of any police officer, city employee or customer.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023) Penalty, see §
110.99
TAVERNS
§ 114.055 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   TAVERN. An establishment primarily engaged in serving alcoholic liquor for
consumption on premises where no food is prepared or served.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)
§ 114.056 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful for any person to operate a tavern without first obtaining a
license to do so. A tavern license does not permit the sales of liquor and a
separate liquor license must also be obtained.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 114.057 INSPECTIONS.
   The Health Officer shall inspect each tavern located within the city at
least annually, and shall make as many additional inspections and reinspections
as shall be necessary for enforcement of this code.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2023)

RETAILERS
§ 115.01 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   RETAILER. Any person or establishment that sells goods to the public for use
or consumption. Retailers include, but are not limited to, clothing stores,
book stores, hardware stores, florists, beauty supply stores, thrift stores,
furniture stores, pet supply stores, cellular telephone stores, electronic
stores, home goods and furnishings stores.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024; Ord. 25-O-2412, passed 7-16-2025)
§ 115.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful for any person to operate as a retailer without first
obtaining a license to do so, unless the retailer holds a separate business
license under this code.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
PHARMACIES
§ 115.10 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PHARMACY. Any establishment where medicine requiring a prescription is sold
or dispensed.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 115.11 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate or maintain a pharmacy without first having obtained
a license to do so.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 115.12 PERIODIC INSPECTIONS.
   The Health Inspector shall from time to time make inspections of the
premises wherein such pharmacy is operated, for the purpose of ascertaining
whether the provisions of this code and all applicable laws of the state are
being complied with.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
GAS STATIONS
§ 115.20 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   GAS STATION. Any premises used for offering fuels, oils and accessories for
motor vehicles for sale at retail to the public.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 115.21 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall maintain or operate a gas station without first having
obtained a license to do so.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 115.22 REGULATIONS.
   (A)   No person shall smoke, and no manager of a gas station shall permit
smoking, in and about a filling station or place where inflammable material is
stored.
   (B)   Repair services, automobile washing and retail convenience sales may
only be incidental services at a gas station.
   (C)   Storage or parking spaces may not be offered for rent at a gas
station.
   (D)   No motor vehicles or boats may be offered for sale or rent at a gas
station.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 115.23 PERIODIC INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   The Fire Inspector shall from time to time inspect, or cause to be
inspected, any such establishment for the purpose of ascertaining whether the
provisions of this code and all applicable laws of the state are being complied
with.
   (B)   If a gas station is engaged in the business of providing food, the
Health Inspector shall from time to time inspect, or cause to be inspected, any
such establishment for the purpose of ascertaining whether the provisions of
this code and all applicable laws of the state are being complied with.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
TOBACCO SALES
§ 115.30 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall maintain or operate any establishment where tobacco of any
kind is kept or sold, without first having obtained a license to do so and, for
the purposes of this subchapter, any cigarette or tobacco vending machine shall
be included within the meaning of this section. A tobacco sales license shall
be in addition to all other business licenses required under this code.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 115.31 SALES TO MINORS.
   No person shall sell, give away or offer to sell or give away any cigars,
cigarettes, tobacco or cigarette wrappers to any person under the age of 21
years.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 115.32 SELF-SERVICE DISPLAYS RESTRICTED.
   It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale, give away or display tobacco
products for sale at any location where the customer can acquire those products
through self-service. All tobacco products shall be displayed from behind a
sales/service counter so that no customer can access tobacco products without
assistance by an employee of a licensee.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 115.33 SALE OF SINGLE OR LOOSE CIGARETTES PROHIBITED.
   (A)   The sale or distribution by any person of a single or loose cigarette
that is not contained within a sealed container, pack or package as provided by
the manufacturer and bearing the federal health warning is prohibited.
   (B)   If any officer, director, manager, associate, member, representative,
agent or employee of a licensed tobacco dealer is found guilty of violating
this section, or if such violation occurs within the licensed premises and with
the knowledge of any officer, director, manager, associate, member,
representative, agent, or employee of a licensed tobacco sales. Such violation
shall be deemed to be the act of the licensed tobacco sales and shall be
grounds for the suspension or revocation of the tobacco sales license, as
herein provided.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99

IN GENERAL
§ 116.001 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   MERCHANT PROVIDING SERVICE. Any person or establishment engaged in the
business of providing a service to the general public for a fee. MERCHANTS
PROVIDING SERVICES includes, but is not limited to barbers, beauticians, nail
salons, machine repair, medical clinics, counseling services, dry cleaners,
educational services, legal services, fitness centers, printing services,
taxicabs, tax preparation services, shipping and postal services, savings and
loan agencies, banks, ambulance services, consulting agencies, and moving
companies.
   CIVIC USE. Those businesses owned or maintained exclusively for educational
or charitable purposes such as schools, libraries, churches and governmental
buildings.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024; Ord. 25-O-2412, passed 7-16-2025)
§ 116.002 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   All merchants providing services shall obtain a business license under this
section unless the business holds a more specific business license required
under this code. Civic uses may be subject to reduced business license fees, as
specified in the Business License Fees Ordinance.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
GENERAL BROKERS
§ 116.010 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   GENERAL BROKER. Any person who negotiates, buys, sells, trades, leases or
handles for another, on a commission basis, or on the basis of compensation in
proportion to the amount of the transaction, any moneys, stocks, bonds,
mortgagee, loans, investments, securities, certificates of indebtedness,
foreign exchange, letters of credit, steamship transportation tickets, grain,
produce, provisions, livestock, goods, ware, merchandise or any other
commodity, article or property (except real property) whether like or unlike
those named in this section, or acts through the medium of another licensed
broker, in the capacity and for any of the purposes in this section.
   INSURANCE BROKER. Any person engaged for others in negotiating contracts for
insurance of any kind or nature, either directly or through any insurance
agent, or with any insurance company other than an insurance company of which
such person shall be an employee.
   REAL ESTATE BROKER. Any person, association, copartnership or corporation,
who for a consideration sells or offers for sale or exchange of real estate, or
who leases, or offers to lease, or rents or offers to rent, any real estate, or
negotiates leases thereof, or of the improvements therein for another or
others; or who employs any person as a real estate sale agent to perform any of
the above acts.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 116.011 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (A)   No person defined as a broker shall operate such business, represent
or hold oneself out as engaging in such business, without first having obtained
a license to do so, subject, however, to the following exception: where more
than one person is employed in a brokerage business, the license fee payable by
the business shall be a single fee paid by the principal or operating agency
and no additional license fee shall be payable by any employee or agent
thereof.
   (B)   No real estate broker shall erect or maintain any sign on any real
estate within the city without first having obtained a city real estate
broker's license.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 116.012 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Applications for licenses required by this chapter shall be made pursuant to
Chapter 110 and also include:
   (A)   The names and residences of all salespersons or brokers who will be
operating under the license applied for.
   (B)   The date and number of the state broker's license, if applicable.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 116.013 PROHIBITED ACTS OF LICENSEE.
   It is unlawful for any licensee under the provisions of this subchapter to
do the following:
   (A)   Make any substantial misrepresentation or engage in untruthful
advertising;
   (B)   Make any false promises of a character likely to influence, persuade
or induce action contrary to the best interests of the city and preservation of
property values in the city;
   (C)   Pursue a continued and flagrant course of misrepresentation or make
false promises through agents, salesperson, advertising or otherwise;
   (D)   Use misleading or untruthful advertising, or use any trade name or
insignia or membership in any real estate or other broker organization of which
the licensee is not a member;
   (E)   Act for more than one party in a transaction without the knowledge of
all parties for whom he or she acts;
   (F)   Fail to furnish copies upon request of all documents relating to a
transaction to all parties executing the same;
   (G)   Pay a commission or valuable consideration to any person for acts or
services performed in violation of this chapter;
   (H)   Employ any person as a salesperson on a purely temporary or single-
deal basis as a means of evading the law regarding payment of commissions or
any of the provisions of this subchapter;
   (I)   Display a "for rent" or "for sale" sign on any property without the
written consent of an owner or his or her duly authorized agent, or advertise
that any property is for sale and for rent in a newspaper or other publication
without the consent of the owner or his or her authorized agent;
   (J)   Fail, within a reasonable time, to provide information requested by
the City Council as a result of a formal or informal complaint to the city,
which would indicate a violation of this subchapter;
   (K)   Solicit for sale, lease or listing for sale or lease, residential real
estate within the city on the ground of loss of value due to the present or
prospective entry into any neighborhood of any person or persons of any
particular race, color, religion or national origin or ancestry; and/or
   (L)   Distribute or cause to be distributed, written material or statements
designed to induce any owner of residential real estate in the city to sell or
lease his or her property because of any present or prospective change in the
race, color, religion or national origin or ancestry of persons in the
neighborhood.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
REFUSE DISPOSAL CONTRACTORS
§ 116.025 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   REFUSE. Includes, but is not limited to, garbage, such as all animal debris,
fruit or vegetable matter and all other substances capable of decay,
fermentation or putrefaction, leaves, grass, paper, waste paper, rags, floor
sweepings, tin cans, glassware, crockery, bottles, ashes, cinders, clinkers and
other household waste, with the exception of stone, dirt or waste material
resulting from landscaping and the remodeling of old or construction of new
buildings.
   REFUSE DISPOSAL CONTRACTOR. Any person, firm or corporation engage in the
business of collecting and disposing of refuse.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 116.026 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful to engage in the business of refuse disposal contracting
without first having obtained a license therefor. Application for such license
shall be in compliance with the general ordinance provisions relating to
licenses as set forth in
Chapter 110 of this code of ordinances.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 116.027 LICENSE FEE.
   The annual license fee for refuse disposal collectors shall per vehicle as
specified in the Business License Fees Ordinance.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 116.028 PROHIBITED ACTS OF LICENSEE.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any refuse disposal contractor to negotiate or
enter into an agreement with individual residents of the city with regard to
the collection of refuse for any period of time not within the term of its
license as issued by the city.
   (B)   It is unlawful for a refuse disposal contractor to accept prepayment
for refuse collection service for any period of time exceeding the expiration
date of his or her license from the city.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 116.029 DUTIES OF LICENSEE.
   It shall be the duty of the licensee to comply fully with the provisions of
this subchapter and terms and conditions of any agreement made by the licensee
with the city or any residents of the city respecting the collection, removal
and disposal of garbage, refuse and ashes as defined in §
116.025 of this chapter.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 116.030 REFUSE VEHICLES SPECIFICATIONS.
   All vehicles used for the collection of garbage, refuse and ashes must be of
the all-metal and totally-enclosed type.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
GROUP HOMES
§ 116.040 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   GROUP HOME. A dwelling unit shared by three or more unrelated persons,
exclusive of staff, who require assistance and/or supervision and who reside
together in a family-type environment as a single housekeeping unit and who are
developmentally disabled, mentally ill, or impaired by chronic illness and/or
mobility limitations with the aging process.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 116.041 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, corporation, association, partnership, religious or other
organization may establish, operate, maintain, offer or advertise a group home
within the city unless that person or entity obtains a business license as
provided herein.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 116.042 APPLICATION.
   Each applicant shall complete an application pursuant to the term of
Chapter 110 which shall also include:
   (A)   The proposed name and location of the group home;
   (B)   The number of residents who will reside within the group home;
   (C)   The number of other persons who will reside within the group home,
classified according to their respective duties and hours they will be present;
   (D)   List of other programs, services, institutions, facilities and
activities operated by the applicant;
   (E)   Current and previous experience with group home programs and/or a
specific plan for developing and securing expertise in the management of a
group home;
   (F)   A letter of explanation regarding the maximum number of residents to
be served, general programming, hours of operation and maximum number and
qualifications of staff to be assigned to the group home;
   (G)   Evidence of appropriate local, state and/or federal licensing,
certification or accreditation for the group home or agency, as required;
   (H)   Building floor plan and plat of survey; and
   (I)   Other information that the Building and Housing Department may
reasonably require.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 116.043 REGULATIONS.
   A group home shall not be occupied by more than eight unrelated persons,
exclusive of staff.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 116.044 INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   The Building and Housing Department shall cause an inspection of the
premises to determine whether it complies with the city's housing, building and
zoning codes.
   (B)   The Fire Department shall cause an inspection to determine whether the
minimum life safety standards of the city and applicable state standards are
met.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
CHILD AND ADULT DAY CARE HOMES
§ 116.060 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ADULT DAY CARE HOME. Any single-family home located in a residential
district and used as a home which regularly provides care for a group of no
more than two up to a maximum of six adults that do not reside in the home, for
a payment of a fee and for less than 24 hours per day. The adults (clients)
must be ambulatory with or without the aid of any assistive devices.
   DAY CARE HOME. Family homes which receive more than three up to a maximum of
12 children for less than 24 hours per day. The number counted includes the
family's natural or adopted children and all other persons under the age of 12.
The term does not include facilities which receive only children from a single
household.
   GROUP DAY CARE HOME. Family homes which receive more than three up to a
maximum of 16 children for less than 24 hours per day. The number counted
includes the family's natural or adopted children and all other persons under
the age of 12.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 116.061 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   A person must apply for and obtain a business license before operating a
child or adult day care home in any residential property within the city. A
person must obtain a separate business license for each residential property
the person operates a child or adult day care home within the city.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 116.062 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   An application for a license to operate a child or adult day care home shall
be made in conformity with the general requirements of Chapter 110 of this code
relating to applications for licenses, and shall additionally contain:
   (A)   The location of the residential property for which a license is
sought;
   (B)   The number of children or adults to be cared for;
   (C)   The number of additional persons inside the home when children are
present;
   (D)   A list of persons who will be working in the child or adult day care
home;
   (E)   A copy of the day care home or group day care home's license issued by
the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services;
   (F)   The name and address of the applicant and a list of all residential
properties owned or occupied by the applicant; and
   (G)   A description of any vehicle proposed to be used for transportation of
children.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 116.063 INVESTIGATION.
   (A)   The Building and Housing Department, upon receipt of an application
for license under this subchapter, shall cause the city's Health Officer,
Director of Building and Housing, Fire Inspector and Police Department to make
a thorough investigation of the premises proposed to be licensed.
   (B)   In addition, the Police Department shall make a thorough investigation
of any transportation vehicle proposed to be used for transportation of any
children.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 116.064 LICENSE DENIAL OR REVOCATION; RENEWAL.
   A license may be denied, suspended or revoked pursuant to Chapter 110 of
this code and for any of the following reasons:
   (A)   Violation of any provisions of this subchapter or of the rules,
regulations and minimum standards promulgated under this subchapter or by the
Illinois Department of Children and Family Services;
   (B)   Cruelty or indifference to the welfare of a child or adult;
   (C)   Conviction of the licensee or any of its employees of a felony or a
misdemeanor as shown by a certified copy of the record of conviction; and
   (D)   Revocation, denial or suspension of the day care/group day care home's
state license.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 116.065 REGULATIONS.
   (A)   The city hereby adopts the "General Requirements for Day Care Homes"
as provided in 89 Ill. Admin. Code. 406.8, and any amendments thereto.
   (B)   Day care/group day care homes shall abide by all statutes and
regulations pertaining to day care homes.
   (C)   The day care/group day care home shall prominently display the city
business license and state license in a conspicuous place.
   (D)   Day care/group day care homes must comply with all building and zoning
codes and may only be located in residential zoning districts.
   (E)   It shall be the responsibility of the licensee to immediately notify
the city of any suspension, revocation or denial of its state license.
   (F)   It shall be the duty of every person conducting or operating a child
day care home or adult day care home to make a report to the city's Health
Officer and the Building Department daily of all cases and suspect cases of
contagious and communicable diseases.
   (G)   No applicant may receive a day care home license if it is in violation
of this code for any other residential property within the city.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 116.066 INSPECTIONS.
   Every day care/group day care home must be open at all reasonable times for
an inspection by the city's Health Officer, Director of Building and Housing
and Fire Inspector as often as is deemed necessary.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99

PEDDLERS
§ 117.01 DEFINITION.
   A PEDDLER is a peddler of goods, wares and merchandise is any person who has
not fixed or permanent place of business and who sells or offers for sale, or
exchange, any goods, wares, merchandise, coal, wood, oil, traveling from place
to place on, along and upon the streets of the city, or who sells and delivers
from any vehicle from place to place any such wares and merchandise.
(Prior Code, § 117.02) (Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 117.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in or operate the business of peddling in the city
any goods, wares and merchandise without first having obtained a license to do
so.
(Prior Code, § 117.02) (Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 117.03 NAME AND ADDRESS TO BE ON VEHICLE.
   Every wagon, cart or other vehicle used by a licensee in and about his or
her business shall have the name of the owner and his or her address plainly
and distinctly painted on the outside of each side of every such wagon, cart or
other vehicle.
(Prior Code, § 117.04) (Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
SOLICITORS
§ 117.20 DEFINITION.
   SOLICITORS are transient merchants or transient vendors, or any person
soliciting orders for the sale of any articles or things in the city to be
delivered in the future, or advertising for or soliciting orders, donations,
gifts or customers for any association, organization, firm, establishment,
person, corporation or business.
(Prior Code, § 117.15) (Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 117.21 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to go from house to house
soliciting funds or subscriptions, or to publicly solicit either in person or
by agent, upon the public streets, sidewalks or any other public place in the
city, subscriptions for charitable or religious or educational or other
organizations or purposes, whether presents or gifts of money or promises are
sought, without having first secured a license therefor.
(Prior Code, § 117.16) (Ord. 71-O-762, passed - -1971; Ord. 24-O-2388, passed
5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 117.22 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   All applicants for a license to solicit within the city shall execute an
application at the Clerk's Office pursuant to
Chapter 110. The application shall additionally include: the name of the firm
or company, organization or association which he represents; the make, year and
model of automobile and license number of the automobile, if any, to be used
while making such solicitations; the article or articles to be solicited, or
purpose for which solicitation is to be made.
(Prior Code, § 117.17) (Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 117.23 ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   (A)   All applications shall be referred to the Mayor and processed in
accordance with the code and other ordinances of the city.
   (B)   The City Clerk shall submit its recommendation to the City Council and
no such permit shall be issued, except upon order of the Council.
(Prior Code, § 117.19) (Ord. 71-O-762, passed - -1971; Ord. 24-O-2388, passed
5-15-2024)
§ 117.24 LICENSE FEES.
   (A)   The fee for a license shall be as specified in the Business License
Fees Ordinance.
   (B)   The City Council shall be empowered to exempt from the provisions of
this subchapter relative to fees any charitable, school or church function
wherein the proceeds of such function are being raised for a charitable or
public purpose.
(Prior Code, § 117.20) (Ord. 71-O-762, passed - -1971; Ord. 24-O-2388, passed
5-15-2024)
§ 117.25 DURATION OF LICENSE.
   A license to solicit within the city shall give the applicant the right and
privilege of soliciting within the city for the purpose named in such
application for a period not to exceed 30 days from the date of the permit.
(Prior Code, § 117.21) (Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 117.26 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   Any license issued hereunder may be suspended or revoked by the Mayor
because of any violation by the licensee of this chapter or of any other
ordinances of the city or of any state or federal law, pursuant to
Chapter 110 of this code.
(Prior Code, § 117.22) (Ord. 71-O-762, passed - -1971; Ord. 24-O-2388, passed
5-15-2024)
§ 117.28 REGULATIONS.
   (A)   No person shall go to any residence or place of business within the
city with the intent or purpose of soliciting as provided in this chapter
without having in his or her possession a license authorizing such solicitation
as provided hereunder.
   (B)   No permit shall be in the possession of any person other than the one
to whom such permit is issued.
   (C)   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to allow any person
under the age of 18 years to publicly solicit either in person or by agent or
representative upon the public streets, sidewalks or any other public place in
the city for subscriptions or donations.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99

MOTOR VEHICLE DEALERS AND MANUFACTURERS
§ 118.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   MOTOR VEHICLE. Any vehicle, machine, truck, tractor-trailer or semi-trailor
propelled or drawn by any mechanical power.
   MOTOR VEHICLE DEALER. Any person engaged in the business of buying, selling
or leasing new or used motor vehicles to consumers, other motor vehicle dealers
or other end users.
   MOTOR VEHICLE MANUFACTURER. Any person engaged in the business of
manufacturing or assembling new or used motor vehicle or motor vehicle parts.
   MOTOR VEHICLE AUCTION. A motor vehicle dealer that sells, solicits and
advertises the sale of used vehicles belonging to others at auction.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 118.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the business of motor vehicle dealer or
manufacturer, without first having obtained a license to do so.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 118.03 REGULATIONS.
   All motor vehicles on display shall be in good working condition and free
from dents, broken glass or broken parts.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
MOTOR VEHICLE REPAIR SERVICE
§ 118.10 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   MOTOR VEHICLE REPAIR SERVICE. Any person engaged in the business of
repairing, rebuilding, maintaining, servicing, painting or modifying a motor
vehicle. MOTOR VEHICLE REPAIR SERVICES include, but are not limited to, auto
repair businesses, oil change businesses, mechanics, muffler repair shops, body
shops and transmission shops.
   EMISSIONS TESTING FACILITY. A facility that tests a motor vehicle's
pollutants for purposes of state and local regulation.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 118.11 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate a motor vehicle repair service or emissions testing
facility without first obtaining a license to do so.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 118.12 REGULATIONS.
   (A)   All repairs, rebuilding, maintenance, service, painting and modifying
of motor vehicles must be conducted indoors.
   (B)   All inoperable motor vehicles, motor vehicles in a state of
disassembly and majorly damaged motor vehicles may not remain outdoors
overnight unless fenced or screened from view on all sides.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
110.99
CAR WASHES
§ 118.20 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CAR WASH. An area or structure equipped with facilities for washing motor
vehicles. CAR WASH includes detail services, self-service, full-service and
automated facilities.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 118.21 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate a car wash without first obtaining a license to do
so. Gas stations that have a car wash on the premises do not require a separate
car wash license.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024; Ord. 25-O-2412, passed 7-16-2025) Penalty,
see §
110.99
§ 118.22 REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Car washes shall abide by all rules governing their operation,
equipment, wastewater, run-off and sludge, including those of the Illinois
Environmental Protection Agency and the Illinois Plumbing Code.
   (B)   The Superintendent of Public Works or his or her designee shall be
authorized to inspect the car washes operation and equipment to ensure
compliance with this code.
   (C)   Car washes shall not store vehicles on site in open view of the public
for a period in excess of 48 hours.
(Ord. 24-O-2388, passed 5-15-2024; Ord. 24-O-2412, passed 7-16-2025) Penalty,
see §
110.99

premises for a short or long term period in exchange for compensation.
   TOW YARD. A temporary holding place for motor vehicles that have been

for a business license.

motor vehicles in a state of disassembly or majorly damages vehicles.

unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CELL TOWER. An elevated structure with antennas, transmitters and receivers
used for the transmission of cellular signals.
   INDUSTRIAL BUSINESS. Includes those premises used for manufacturing or
construction of goods, warehousing, storage and distributing of manufactured
goods, cell towers, transportation dispatch, motor freight terminals and
miscellaneous trucking businesses.
   MISCELLANEOUS TRUCKING BUSINESS. All businesses associated with the

is assembled and/or stored for outing in intrastate and interstate shipment by
motor truck.

§ 120.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CONTRACTOR. Any person, partnership, corporation, or other business entity
engaged in the business of constructing, altering or repairing buildings or
other structures or lots and all trades and crafts associated with such work,
including, but restricted to, general building contractors, excavating
contractors, landscape and lawncare professionals tree removal, fence
contractors, snow plowing contractors. cement or concrete contractors, asphalt
contractors, masonry contractors, carpentry contractors, heating, air
conditioning, ventilating, mechanical, electrical and plumbing contractors and
subcontractors.
      (1)   Any person who engages in the construction, repair or alteration of
any building or structure within the city for which a building permit is
required, is presumed to be a CONTRACTOR, and must be licensed hereunder unless
such presumption is rebutted.
      (2)   A homeowner engaged in constructing, altering, or repairing his,
her or their personal residence or lot shall not be considered a CONTRACTOR for
purposes of this chapter.
   GENERAL CONTRACTOR. A contractor who uses one or more trades or
subcontractors to perform the required construction to complete any project for
which a building permit is required.
   HOMEOWNER. A person or trust that has purchased a property with the
intention of making it his, her or their primary residence for a period of at
least six months. Corporation or other business entities listed as
beneficiaries shall not be considered homeowners.
   LANDSCAPE and LAWN CARE PROFESSIONAL. Any person that employs one or more
individuals for the purpose of providing landscape maintenance for clients,
including, without limitation, the cultivating or beautifying of gardens; the
trimming of hedges, plants or grass; or the raking or sweeping of debris and
leaves; snow removal.
   LANDSCAPE MAINTENANCE. The improvement and/or maintenance of the appearance
of an area of land by planting and/or maintaining trees, shrubs, grass or other
plants and lawn ornaments; or by altering the contour of the ground.
   PERSON. A living human being also known as a natural person.
   SUBCONTRACTORS. A contractor who performs only that type of work that is
classified as a trade (for example plumbing, electrical, and the like).
   VEHICLE. Any motor-driven vehicle used by the licensee to transport a work
crew, equipment, yard waste and/or debris.
   YARD WASTE. Leaves with twig stems no longer than four inches, grass
clippings and similar garden debris and waste, tree branches, limbs and other
similar wood materials; unusable or unwanted substances of organic garden or
yard material.
(Ord. 14-O-2099, passed 8-20-2014; Ord. 23-O-2373, passed 10-4-2023; Ord. 24-O-
Ord. 2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 120.02 LICENSES REQUIRED.
   (A)   No person shall act or perform any services as a contractor or
subcontractor within the city without first having obtained a contractor's
license therefor as provided in this chapter.
   (B)   No person shall operate a construction or landscape business within
the city without first having obtained a business license therefor.
   (C)   A separate license for snow removal by a landscape and lawn care
professional or any snow removal contractor is required.
   (D)   Each vehicle operated by a landscape contractor or snow removal
contractor shall at all times display a sticker in the front driver's side
window that will be issued by the city's Building and Housing Department upon
the completion and approval of a contractor's license application.
   (E)   Exemptions.
      (1)   Homeowners. The homeowner shall not be required to acquire a city
contractor license to perform replacement and/or repair work on his, her or
their primary residence.
      (2)   Plumbers. Illinois Department of Public Health licensed plumbing
contractor and licensed plumber or as expressed in state statutes.
(Ord. 14-O-2099, passed 8-20-2014; Ord. 23-O-2373, passed 10-4-2023; Ord. 24-O-
2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
120.99
§ 120.03 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   All applications for a contractor's license shall be made in writing to the
Building and Housing Department, upon forms furnished by the city. Each
application shall be in accordance with
Chapter 110 of this code and additionally state the name and business address
of the applicant, whether it is a contractor, subcontractor or landscape and
lawncare professional license application and if applicable, the trade, or
trades involved who would be operating under such license and a statement that
the applicant is familiar with all pertinent city ordinances, code and
regulations including building codes and agrees to fully comply with same.
(Ord. 14-O-2099, passed 8-20-2014; Ord. 23-O-2373, passed 10-4-2023; Ord. 24-O-
2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 120.04 BOND AND INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Bonds. Each applicant for a license shall, before receiving such a
license, deposit with the Building and Housing Department a license and letter
of credit or permit bond issued by a company approved and authorized to issue
bonds by the state in a form suitable to the city in the following penal sums:
      (1)   As set by the City Council for a general contractor in the amount
of $10,000; or
      (2)   As set by the City Council for a subcontractor in the amount of
$10,000.
   (B)   Liability insurance. A certificate of insurance showing that the
applicant has both bodily injury and property damage coverage in the amount of
$1,000,000 for each occurrence and $2,000,000 in the aggregate. The certificate
of insurance must name the city as the certificate holder.
   (C)   Prior to any license being issued, the contractor and/or subcontractor
must present proof to the city that they or their company are licensed and
bonded.
(Ord. 14-O-2099, passed 8-20-2014; Ord. 23-O-2373, passed 10-4-2023; Ord. 24-O-
2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
120.99
§ 120.05 LICENSE FEE AND TERM.
   The license fee for contractors and subcontractors shall be stated in the
Business License Fees Ordinance.
(Ord. 14-O-2099, passed 8-20-2014; Ord. 23-O-2373, passed 10-4-2023; Ord. 24-O-
2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 120.06 DUTIES; REMOVAL OF REFUSE; TRAFFIC OBSTRUCTION.
   (A)   A contractor who is licensed under this chapter shall secure the
appropriate and necessary building permits required by the city before
undertaking the building, constructing, rehabilitating, repairing, altering,
moving or demolishing any building, structure, sidewalk, street, fence,
swimming pool, driveway, HVAC equipment or landscaping or any other related
construction activity, including plumbing and electrical work.
   (B)   Such contractor shall comply with all provisions of this code of
ordinances relating to or regulating the activities of contractors.
   (C)   All contractors shall remove or cause to be removed, at least once a
week or, at the direction of the Building and Housing Department, all trash,
refuse and other waste materials accumulated as a result of the construction
activity at the site of construction.
   (D)   No contractor shall obstruct traffic, streets or sidewalks without
first receiving permission from the Mayor's Office of the city.
   (E)   The contractor shall restrict the movement of construction vehicles
exceeding the local weight limitations to the local streets approved by the
appropriate city department.
   (F)   No contractor shall permit dirt, mud or waste materials to fall or be
carried onto the public streets or walkways.
   (G)   Any accumulation of dirt, mud or waste materials shall be removed from
the public streets or walkways on a daily basis by the contractor.
   (H)   In newly established residential and commercial/industrial
subdivisions in which more than one contractor may be building, the developer
shall be held responsible for compliance with this section.
   (I)   The contractor shall at all times keep the site of activities in an
orderly condition, free from standing water, unguarded dangerous implements and
health and safety hazards.
   (J)   At all times when work is being performed, contractor shall have at
least one individual on site who is experienced in the type of work being
performed, understands and can read the project's plans and specifications, and
can effectively communicate.
   (K)   Contractors shall either remove all yard waste from the premises at
the conclusion of each work day; or bag all yard waste in brown paper yard
waste bags and place said waste bags in rear of premises. Under no
circumstances shall yard waste be left on the premises in plastic garbage waste
bags.
   (L)   Snow removed cannot be placed on streets or sidewalks.
(Ord. 14-O-2099, passed 8-20-2014; Ord. 23-O-2373, passed 10-4-2023; Ord. 24-O-
2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
120.99
§ 120.07 INSPECTION AND ENFORCEMENT.
   The provisions of this chapter are declared to be of a regulatory nature,
and it shall at all times be the right of the Police Department, Fire
Department, Department of Public Works, Building and Housing Department and
other city departments to regularly inspect the site of contractors' activities
to see that the same are being conducted and operated in accordance with the
requirements of all laws and ordinances applicable thereto.
(Ord. 14-O-2099, passed 8-20-2014; Ord. 23-O-2373, passed 10-4-2023; Ord. 24-O-
2388, passed 5-15-2024)
§ 120.08 LICENSE SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION.
   (A)   The city may suspend or revoke a contractor or subcontract license
under this chapter pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 110 of this code.
   (B)   Any such suspension or revocation shall be in addition to any fine
imposed for the conduct giving rise to the revocation or suspension. No person
whose license has been revoked as herein provided shall be eligible for a new
license for a one-year period from the date of revocation or suspension.
   (C)   No person whose license has been revoked two times previously or whose
license and permit bond has been collected on in any amount two times
previously shall be eligible for licensing for five years from the date of the
last revocation.
(Ord. 14-O-2099, passed 8-20-2014; Ord. 23-O-2373, passed 10-4-2023; Ord. 24-O-
2388, passed 5-15-2024) Penalty, see §
120.99
§ 120.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any contractor or anyone performing the
services of a contractor to violate any of the terms or provisions of this
chapter.
   (B)   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined
in the amount of not less than $200, nor more than $750.
   (C)   A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day such
violation is committed or permitted to continue and shall be punishable as such
hereunder.
   (D)   The city may also file a claim against the contractor's licensing and
permit bond (L&P bond) or otherwise proceed as specified in this code of
ordinances.
   (E)   If a vehicle is being used by a landscape and lawn care professional
or snow removal contractor without a vehicle sticker, as required under §
120.02 of this chapter, that vehicle shall be towed at the owner's expense.
(Ord. 14-O-2099, passed 8-20-2014; Ord. 23-O-2373, passed 10-4-2023; Ord. 24-O-
2388, passed 5-15-2024)
